story: The -year-old royal showed no sign of any sleepless nights as he left his newborn son and we Meghan Markle at home to launch the Games countdown in Holland.The Duke of Sussex skipped his paternity leave to travel to the Hague this morning, having yesterday introduced the couples amazing baby boy to the world.And despite his son being just days old, Harry appeared to be full of energy as he arrived at The Hague to launch the one-year countdown to the Invictus Games  - a sporting event he created.During a later tour of the park, the Prince was spotted wearing an Invictus jumper bearing the slogan I am daddy.He was even given a blue baby toy, apparently a rattle, from seven-year-old girl Daimy Gommers whose dad Paul lost a leg in a parachute accident.Harry was later given an Invictus themed baby-gro, holding it up to the audience in delight as he exclaimed: Its lovely.And he showed any sleepless night didnt put him off his game, managing to get a bullseye as he tried his hand at archery at Sportcampus Zuiderpark.Gushing to Netherlands athlete Dennis van der Stroon, the Prince reportedly said that having a baby was his new focus.Dennis said: Above all he said he was just amazed by the miracles in the world and how his child has made a lot of people happy.Hes told me hes really happy that his son is so far very quiet.He also told me not to make too many plans and that theres no way you can plan for when the baby arrives.The prince had initially been scheduled to travel to the nation on Wednesday for a two day visit, however, it was announced last week that his trip had been shortened to just one day as -year-old Meghan’s due date came and went.It is understood todays launch has been a long-standing engagement for Harry, who has passionately advocated for injured armed services personnel.Speaking today at the event, the Prince said: I had seen first-hand the transformative power of sport in helping people physically and psychologically recover and knew that the Invictus Games would change lives, capture hearts and inspire a generation, the Invictus generation.Now here we are, launching the countdown to the fth Invictus Games and I am absolutely thrilled that many more wounded, injured and sick Servicemen and women will have the opportunity to continue their journey to recovery.While the trip had been cut short, leading parenting expert Suzie Hayman said the new dad would find leaving his baby son and we so soon agonising.She added that he would feel a pang to be leaving his we and child.It had previously been reported Prince Harry would take two weeks paternity leave on the birth of his baby to show he was a modern dad.And Buckingham Palace today announced Harry would continue his royal duties into next week - heading to Oxford Childrens Hospital next Tuesday.A friend of the prince said: He doesnt need to take paternity leave because he doesnt work in the way most people do but he thinks its a very modern dad thing to do.Harry had appeared every inch the doting dad yesterday as he held his swaddled son Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, who was born on Monday morning.As Meghan put a protective arm around her two guys, the father gushed: Parenting is amazing.Its only been two and a half days, three days, but were just so thrilled to have our own little bundle of joy and be able to spend some precious times with him as he slowly, slowly starts to grow up.And the bearded royal even joked his son already had a little bit of facial hair as he showed him off to the cameras.Meghan, who is being supported by her mum Doria Ragland, is believed to be staying with Archie at the couples newly renovated home at Frogmore Cottage in Windsor.The new mum, who stunned in a white trench coat dress for yesterdays announcement, had kept a close arm around her husband and son.She said: Its magic. Its pretty amazing.I have the best two guys in the world so Im really happy. He has the sweetest temperament. Hes really calm.The couple broke with royal convention by not using a title for their baby boy, and have given their firstborn a name familiar to fans of the American Archie comic - featuring a main character who has red hair just like the duke.While some suggested that Archie had been chosen thanks to it meaning bold - a royal source said: They may have just liked the name - indicating it may be another sign of the fiercely independent couple wishing to break with tradition.Little Archie yesterday met the Queen and Prince Philip as the couple shared sweet snaps of their new family on Instagram.Archie means genuine, bold and brave, and is German in origin.Short for Archibald, it is now given as a name in its own right.Famous Archies include the actress Archie Panjabi, who starred in The Good We.Archie Andrews is the main character in Archie comics in America and also the Netflix show Riverdale, while Archie Mitchell was a villain in the BBC soap EastEnders.Harrison means son of Harry so is likely to be a tribute to the duke.It is English in origin and famous Harrisons include the Star Wars actor Harrison Ford.Archie was the th most popular name for boys in England and Wales in , according to the latest available figures from the Office for National Statistics.It has experienced a dramatic rise in popularity since  when it was only in nd place.Some , baby boys were named Archie in England and Wales in .In Scotland, Archie was the th most popular name for boys in , according to the National Records of Scotland. And the Royal Family have all flooded the new parents with messages of congratulations.Prince William and Kate Middleton said they were thrilled at the news - with big brother William happy to welcome Harry to the sleep deprivation society.Askedhe had any pearls of wisdom for Harry, dad-of-three William laughed and said: “Plenty of advice, plenty of advice.But no, I wish him all the best and I hope the next few days they can settle down and enjoy having a newborn in their family and the joys that come with that.”Meanwhile, grandfather Prince Charles joked he was collecting a rather large number of grandchildren.The -year-old was gted a teddy bear and blue balloon as he arrived in Germany with we Camilla.The Queen, who was the first to be told of Baby Sussexs arrival, also revealed her pleasure at welcoming her eighth great grandchild.

title: vegan dad starved toddler australia
story: Aussie cops were horried to find the -month-old girl appearing floppy and unable to even crawl or talk.The girl had suffered fractures all over her body.Her bones had become so brittle and medics believe they could have been broken by normal handling.Police claim the father,  and mother, , — who cannot be named for legal reasons — fed their child a very strict diet “severely lacking in nutrients for her to thrive”.They first faced court last May after the toddler suffered a seizure at home.Yesterday, Downing Centre Court in Sydney, Australia heard details of girls shocking diet.The mum insisted her child was a fussy eater so she was only fed one cup of oats, a piece of toast and oats again for dinner.But this diet left the child suffering from rickets, as she had severe deficiencies in a large range of nutrients needed for growth and development.Rickets is a preventable bone disease that affects babies and young children and causes soft and weakened bones. She was taken to hospital to be checked over, and doctors discovered she did not have a birth certicate, a medical number, had not been to any follow-up appointments and had not had any immunisations since birth.The baby was handed over to a foster carer in August . The carer told the court how traumatised the child was.In a statement to the court, she said: I remember thinking, ‘how terrying’, as the baby was so behind other children.Strangers were even struck by just how small she was.“She begins to scream and cryshe goes into a medical room and the door is closed, the carer added.Today, Judge Sarah Huggett blasted the -year-old dads claims that he was powerless in helping his child.The dad claimed it was the mum who dictated the household.But the judge told the court: She wasn’t walking or talking, she wasn’t hitting milestones.“He did nothing. He could have picked her up and taken her to a doctor.“He is older than the mother and could have just as easily have done something.“I do not accept that he was powerless.”The father’s lawyer said his client is now living in Queensland and has been subject to an “vegan and anti-vax witch hunt” in the press.The parents first faced court in May last year, two months after their toddler suffered a seizure at home. They both pleaded guilty to failing to provide for a child and causing serious injury.The sentencing hearing continues.A version of this story originally appeared on news.au

title: pink dolphin gives birth to calf
story: The unusual creature, known as Pinky, has been seen swimming with a pink baby in the Calcasieu river in Louisiana.The candyfloss-coloured creature shot to fame  years ago when she was spotted swimming alongside her mum.Captain Erik Rue was the first to spot her and claims hes seen her swimming with other dolphins and mating, describing her as being very sexually active.Now footage shared to Facebook appears to show Pinky with a calf of her own.The clip, which was shared by Thomas Adams, shows the pair jumping in the wake of a boat.Pinky appears to be a Pink River Dolphin, whose striking colouring is believed to be caused by a genetic mutation.The species is classied as endangered to vulnerable and their population is estimated to be in the tens of thousands.The birth of Pinkys calf has sparked further hopes that the babies of pink dolphins could share their mothers colouring, which could even double the current population.Captain Rue claims Pinkys whole body is  per cent pink unlike other dolphins, whose belies are the only parts of them that are this colour.He told KATC: Surprisingly, it does not appear to be drastically affected by the environment or sunlight as might be expected considering its condition, although it tends to remain below the surface a little more than the others in the pod.Mr Rue added: I feel very fortunate to have seen this incredible mammal and lucky to be able to work and live in the area where such a fantastic creature frequents.Our guests are always thrilled at the opportunity to spot such a unique mammal and we look forward to it being around for some time to come.

title: women hormone treatment progesterone prevents miscarriage
story: Women who suffer bleeding during their first weeks of pregnancy could improve their chances of having a baby by taking progesterone, experts said.The team from the University of Birmingham said an estimated , babies lives per year in the UK could be saved.They carried out a trial on , pregnant women who presented early pregnancy bleeding at  UK hospitals.Expectant mums were randomly assigned by computer into one of two groups - one group of , women who were given mg of progesterone twice daily as a vaginal pessary, while the other group of , were given a placebo.While the study did not show that progesterone could help all women who suffered early pregnancy bleeding, it was found to help those who had suffered a previous miscarriage.Of the  women given progesterone who had previously had one or two miscarriages, went on to have a live birth, compared with  women out of  in the placebo group .The benefit was greater for the women who had suffered three or more miscarriages, with a  per cent increase in the live birth rate in the progesterone group compared with the placebo group.Of  women with three or more previous miscarriages, went on to have a live birth, compared with  per centof women in the placebo group.The PRISM trial, which was funded by the National Institute for Health Researchand published in the New England Journal of Medicine, was the largest of its kind.Arri Coomarasamy, professor of gynaecology at the University of Birmingham and director of Tommys National Centre for Miscarriage Research, said: The role of progesterone in women with early pregnancy bleeding has been studied and debated for about  years, however what we have previously lacked is high-quality evidence.The largest study before the PRISM trial had less than  participants, whereas our study had more than , participants and was of very high quality, which means we can be confident in our findings.Samantha Allen, , from Bradford, West Yorkshire, suffered a miscarriage in December  and was recruited to the PRISM trial in June  when she was nine weeks pregnant.She and her husband Stephen, , welcomed son Noah in February .It was on my birthday in November  when I found out that I was pregnant - it was the best birthday gt I could have hoped for, she said.However, my joy soon started to turn to concern when I began having some bleeding when I was around seven weeks pregnant and I ended up in AE.I had a scan and was told to come back on Christmas Eve for another scan.But then, on December , I started bleeding quite heavily and had to call an ambulance.I was taken to AE where I was told the baby had died when I was eight weeks pregnant and I was miscarrying.The following day, on Christmas Eve, I had to also go through the trauma of miscarriage surgery.Around  months later she found out she was pregnant again, but after seven weeks she began spotting and decided to go to the early pregnancy unit.She had a scan and was told they could detect a heartbeat but couldnt be certain so she was booked for a scan two weeks later.Samantha continued: The spotting continued during those two weeks so I was relieved when the second scan showed I was pregnant.Thats when they told me about the PRISM trial and I decided to take part.I was prescribed progesterone pessaries which I self-administered until I was  weeks pregnant.The bleeding stopped within a week of starting the trial.Noah was born weighing a healthy lb oz and is now -months-old.She concluded: Of course, well never know whether or not I would have miscarriedI had not taken part in the trial, orI had been part of the group that received the placebo.Either way, I feel fortunate and happy that I did participate.I hope the results of the trial will make a dference to the way women receive treatment moving forwards, and that I had a small part to play in that.Our finding that women who are at risk of a miscarriage because of current pregnancy bleeding and a history of a previous miscarriage could benefit from progesterone treatment has huge implications for practice.This treatment could save thousands of babies who may have otherwise been lost to a miscarriage.We hope that this evidence will be considered by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellenceand that it will be used to update national guidelines for women at risk of miscarriage.Jane Brewin, chief executive of the Tommys baby charity, said: The results from this study are important for parents who have experienced miscarriage - they now have a robust and effective treatment option which will save many lives and prevent much heartache.It gives us confidence to believe that further research will yield more treatments and ultimately make many more miscarriages preventable.Dr Adam Devall, senior clinical trial fellow at the University of Birmingham and manager of Tommys National Centre for Miscarriage Research, said: Miscarriage is a common complication of pregnancy, affecting one in five women, and vaginal bleeding in early pregnancy is associated with a one in three risk of miscarriage.Several small studies have suggested that administering progesterone, a hormone essential for maintaining a pregnancy, may reduce the risk of miscarriage in women presenting with early pregnancy bleeding.

title: marks spencer chicken vindaloo kebab shop sandwich
story: The supermarket has already brought out the curry filling which it boasts could be the hottest in the world, which punters cant wait to try.But MS has followed it up by announcing it is planning on bringing out the spiced mint lamb doner meat one.Its led to some shoppers at the swanky supermarket to get all hot and bothered for the fiery new flavours.MS tweeted: “Were planning a sandwich showdown.Vote for our next flavour and only the winner will get its chance to shine on shelves.What will you pick: Kebab Shop with spiced lamb OR a BBQ classic, Smokehouse Chicken Pick your #MyMarksFave – the winner will be in store later this month!Nearly , people have voted and Smokehouse Chicken has  per cent of the vote.Kieran Timothy wrote: I love spicy food, and safe to say the Marks  Spencer chicken vindaloo sandwich hits that brief! #BurningTongue.And another wrote: Sandwich news! The MS vindaloo  sandwich is a fairly spicy and quite nice sandwich.One user who also tried the sandwich tweeted: It is surprisingly spicy, and definitely the [spiciest] sandwich Ive ever bought from a shop..  would get hiccups for again.It comes days after MS proudly announced the vindaloo sarnie is already on sale.They tweeted: “Red alert. Is this the hottest sandwich in the world “Our new Chicken Vindaloo Sandwich is hotter than hot. Packed with marinated chicken, a FIERY tomato sauce and chargrilled red peppers.“Tag a friend to take the spicy sarnie challenge – can they stand the heat ”Of course, not everyone was overjoyed with the sizzling new sarnie.One shopper said: “Had that new MS chicken vindaloo sandwich for lunch and didn’t think it would be that punchy, but it has proper f***ed me up.”Another added: “Why did I think buying MS new Vindaloo sandwich would be a good idea, sweating like a pig on a spit roast, mouths on fire.“Teach me for doing the typical ‘Oh I can handle spice’ like the moron I am #d***head #somuchpain.”It comes after MS faced a backlash last week over its LGBT sandwich.An MS spokesman said: “MS offers over  dferent sandwich options, with favourite fillings such as Prawn Mayo, BLT and Cheddar Cheese Ploughman’s dominating our bestsellers.“Each season we introduce new fillings to the range and for this summer we’re adding eight street food inspired sandwiches and wraps and are asking customers to help us choose the flavours they’d most like to see in store.”

title: victory day humiliation putin military parade
story: The procession - which marked the th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany - included thousands of troops and a vast array of the latest military hardware.This year marked the first time women were allowed to march through Red Square with the honour guard as Putins femme fatale troops put on a show of real girl power.The Kremlin was earlier forced to scrap a major military flypast over Red Square at the last minute today after it threatened to rain on his parade.The risk of thunder over Moscow meant the airshow at the Victory Day procession - marking the th anniversary of the end of WWII - had to be axed.It was a second blow for Putin after other world leaders were conspicuous by their absence at the much-heralded ceremony.The Kremlin insisted it had not invited foreign heads of state but next years th anniversary would be marked with greater pomp.However, there was some joy for Putin as his Hollywood hardman pal Steven Seagal was among the dignitaries.This mornings march-past by , troops along with tanks and missile carriers still went ahead - and was watched by millions on state TV.It began at am in Moscow - am London time - with other commemorations mirrored in cities across Russias  time zones.Putin  reviewed the parade from a tribune packed with Soviet war veterans, some of whom wore rows of campaign medals and clutched red roses.We have done and will do everything necessary to ensure the high level of readiness of our armed forces, Putin said.One group of boys and girls aged around six werew event spotted parading with mini models of the American M rle.The startling news comes amid claims of a growing militarisation within Russia amid rising tensions with the West.Putins Yunarmia - likened to the Hitler Youth - which offers military training to kids  - now has , members.We call on all countries to recognise our common responsibility to create a security system that is effective and equal for everyone.Almost half of Russians plan to attend Victory Day military parades and commemorative processions, according to the Kremlin.On display in Moscow were mighty Yars nuclear missile and the Pantsir-SA surface-to-air missile system, designed to operate in the Arctic.Russias Yars mobile intercontinental nuclear missile launcher and its advanced S- air defence missile system, which Moscow has deployed in Syria, were also on show.However, some   warplanes and helicopters were banned from flying over the Kremlin by the last minute decision.Russian authorities normally spike clouds around Moscow with a chemical cocktail to change the weather” for major Red Square occasions to ensure sunshine.But it appears that the technology failed to work this year.The Soviet-era system means that while  Red Square is bathed in sunshine, villages outside Moscow are drenched with rain.A fleet of Antonov-  aircraft are deployed to ‘spike’ clouds with a chemical cocktail of weather-changing silver iodide, liquid nitrogen and dry ice.Russian officials indicated the cloud-spiking had taken place ahead of today’s parade - but did not explain why it failed.The cancellation came four days after a Sukhoi SuperJet  crashed at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo airport while making an emergency landing after it was “hit by lightning”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: disgraced fifa chief sepp blatter demands return luxury watches
story: He also wants pension payments and for his former employer to clear his name.Blatter, , said as many as  watches from brands like Patek Philippe, IWC and Omega hadnt been ed to him since he was ousted in October .The watches are estimated to be worth between £, and £, a piece.Blatter became Fa president in  and in the following years he allegedly engaged in money laundering and took bribes when deciding upon the location for World Cups.He was forced to resign two years ago after Fa’s ethics committee found him guilty of accepting an improper payment of two million Swiss franc from Uefa chief Michel Platini.The associations former president has now revealed hes planning to file a lawsuit against Fa which will also include demands for pension payments and clarication about his compensation arrangements to show that I am not a thief.He told the New York Times: This is a question of respect, and I’ve reached the end of my temper.I think it’s not too much to ask to give me back personal belongings.Last year Blatter, who is banned from football until , was given back  watches, though this was not part of his high technology collection which he claims still hasnt been ed.FIFA’s deputy secretary general, Alasdair Bell said Blatter received all the watches hed requested but later claimed some were missing.We did what was asked of us, Bell said.He added that Blatter receives what hes legally entitled to in person payments.Bell continued: If he files a claim, obviously we’ll defend any claims on the basis we act in conformity of our legal obligations, including with Mr Blatter.

title: jeremy corbyn arsenal fan tottenham ajax
story: The Labour boss said he was pleased to see Tottenham make it to the Champions League final - despite holding a season ticket at the Gunners.Fellow Arsenal fans accused Mr Corbyn of being a sellout and blasted: Thats not how it works mate.Spurs beat Ajax last night thanks to a th-minute goal - sending the North London team through to the final against Liverpool.Mr Corbyn tweeted: Even an Arsenal fan can appreciate the astonishing performances by @LFC and @SpursOfficial over the last two nights.Two underdogs defying the odds to set up an all English Champions League Final. Congratulations and good luck to both teams in the final.But he was mercilessly roasted online for being disloyal to his own team.One fan joked: Take this mans membership away now, Arsenal!Another added: Thats not how it works mate. We appreciate Liverpools performance and it stops there.Catherine Yeboah blasted: Appreciating Liverpools performance is one thing. That lot from up the Seven Sisters Road  Not a chance.Sean McKenzie quipped: David Cameron is a West Ham Villa fan but I bet even hell appreciate the incredible achievements of Liverpool Rovers and Tottenham United in those two football heats!And another web user stormed: No Arsenal fan would wish Spurs anything but a footballing disaster. title: queen windsor horse show meeting baby archie
story: The -year-old monarch was one of the first people to meet Archie Harrison after proud parents Prince Harry and Meghan Markle showed off their son tot he world yesterday.Her Majesty today headed to the Royal Windsor Horse Show in Windsor, Berkshire - indulging her love in horses.While the Queen doesnt gamble on the races, she is said to read the Racing Post over breakfast every morning.The visit comes after the doting great-gran got to meet the newest addition to the Royal Family - Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor.The infant’s grandmother — Meghan’s mum Doria Ragland,  — was also at the ­historic meeting.A royal source said: “It’s an incredible moment.“With Doria also there it marks a historic new chapter for the Royal Family.”And the Queen was clearly excited about the new arrival, having exclaimed eight when asked how many great-grandchildren she now has.The meeting came after Harry, , and Meghan, , announced the name of their first child as simply Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor.Prince Harry - who today headed to the Hague today just three days after his son was born - and Meghan had seemed delighted as they introduced their son to the world yesterday.The father gushed: Parenting is amazing. Its only been two and a half days, three days, but were just so thrilled to have our own little bundle of joy and be able to spend some precious times with him as he slowly, slowly starts to grow up.And the bearded royal even joked his son already had a little bit of facial hair as he showed him off to the cameras.Meghan, who stunned in a white trench coat dress for yesterdays announcement, added: Its magic. Its pretty amazing.I have the best two guys in the world so Im really happy. He has the sweetest temperament. Hes really calm.The parents later announced Archies name - a surprise for some who had hoped Harry would include Spencer as a nod to mum Princess Diana’s maiden name.Their choice means the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have formally chosen not to use a title for their newborn.As the first-born son of a duke, Archie could have become Earl of Dumbarton — one of Harry’s subsidiary titles. But instead he will simply be Master Archie Mountbatten-Windsor.Archie, short for Archibald, is a name of German origin and means “bold or brave”. Harrison is of English origin — and means “son of Harry”.The hyphenated surname Mountbatten-Windsor is in keeping with a royal tradition established by the Queen to dferentiate her direct descendants from the rest of the House of Windsor.The Queen has been around horses from her early childhood, with her first riding lesson taking place when she was just four at the Buckingham Palace Mews.She was given a Shetland pony named Peggy as a child, going on to follow the sport throughout her le.Her passion has also been passed down to the rest of the royal family, with Princess Anne and Zara Tindall both known for their equestrian talents.

title: builders dump huge mound of soil outside homes
story: The elderly residents say the ft high “soil bund” has blighted their views of the countryside surrounding their quiet cul-de-sac in Doncaster.Retired couple Alan Boutell, , and his we Doreen, , are among residents who say the mound has completely ruined their view.Some homeowners even believe it has caused house prices to plummet - with one property being placed on the market for £, less than the average for the street.The mound was constructed in October last year by Gazeley - a developer which is in the process of constructing two huge warehouses on land behind the street.However, residents of the street have reacted with anger after their landscape view was spoilt because “the pile of muck” is just metres behind their gardens.Alan, a former digger driver, doesnt understand why the company have left the mound.He said: When it was first left, we all thought it would just be temporary. But, nearly six months later, its still there.Nobody can believe it. The company could make it lower or less visible.Alans we Doreen, said she fought the original plans for the construction of the warehouses with other residents on the street.She said the council ignored the pleas of many of the elderly homeowners.Doreen said: We used to be able to see the countryside when we sat out in the garden.Now all we can see is a huge pile of muck.Bunds are among the most common techniques used in agriculture to collect surface run-off, increase water infiltration and prevent soil erosion.Alan and Doreens neighbour John Hotterwell, , has been left outraged by the horric site at the rear of his home.As John only has a very small garden, he used to enjoy sitting in his bedroom to enjoy the view of horses and countryside.Due to the huge mud mound being placed directly behind his home, he now says he cant even see the sky.John, a retired construction worker who lives with we Brenda, , said: I used to watch the horses going past the back of the house.All I can see when I look outside is soil and pylons. During the winter, it was literally pitch black for months.We dont have a view anymore, it is completely ruined.Roy Sykes, Doncaster Councils Head of Planning, said: The embankments are designed to act as a noise and visual buffer between residents and the proposed industrial development.They have been built to the approved height but following construction we have been made aware that some residents are unhappy with their size.We are currently discussing potential alterations which address these concerns as well as ensuring the bunds remain an effective screen to the neighbouring employment use.A spokesperson for developer Gazeley said: We have been working with the council to ensure that the construction and bunds have as little of an impact as possible.We have been liaising with the Local Planning Authority to discuss the possibility of obtaining a consent for alternative landscaping or potential fencing to deter people from walking on the bunds.These discussions are ongoing and we hope to find a solution for residents.

title: amber rudd vows to slash three year benefits sanctions for brits on universal credit down to six months
story: The Work and Pensions boss said the penalties undermined the process of helping people back to work and werent always effective.In her first major speech on the world of work, she said in London today: While necessary for the integrity of the system, I believe long financial sanctions become much less valuable over time, and ultimately undermine our aim to help people into work.That is why we will reduce theof the maximum sanction to six months to make them more proportionate, and why I have already launched an evaluation to consider further improvements we can make.The changes wont come into effect until the end of the year, however.She also revealed she is doing a review into the effectiveness of the sanctions to decide whether to make more changes later on.And she admitted the punishments - which are given out when claimants miss their appointments or dont search for enough work - could have damaged the Tory brand.Labour welcomed the move, saying there was clear evidence that sanctions do not help people into sustained employment.Margaret Greenwood added: They also cause stress and anxiety for many and are one of the key reasons that people ask for help at food banks.And the Child Poverty Action Group said: We hope this is the start of a dferent approach to sanctions.DWP data shows that there were , Brits who had their benefits slashed for longer than  months since .Meanwhile, Ms Rudd laid out her vision for a more compassionate Tory party today - in a thinly-veiled leadership pitch to take over from Theresa May.Ms Rudd also revealed she wanted to make it easier for Brits to swap jobs and move into higher paid work, by working with job centre coaches to encourage people to climb the career ladder.And she said Brits have to embrace technological changes rather than simply glory the jobs of the past.Ms Rudd, a key ally of the PM, said work coaches will be able to be more flexible in submitting their childcare costs on Universal Credit too.The DWP boss said her department needed to help every worker, no matter what their background, get into a job, and move up in their careers.But she refused to confirm or deny whether she would run for the top job when the PM steps down.Ms Rudd said she was committed to the DWP and she was enjoying the role shes got now.However, shes previously said she was thinking about running.Ms Rudd urged Tories to hold our never and allow Mrs May to try and get Brexit sorted out.She said it was a complicated progress and hopefully we can do a deal with Labour,not, indicative votes on the way forward.And warning that No Deal would cost jobs and our economy, she said she wouldnt be comfortable with leaving the EU with nothing in place.

title: prankster cons asda worker into announcing tesco is cheaper
story: Michael Bidgood, , pulled the prank in Manchester’s Trafford Park by calling the supermarket’s number from his mobile.He managed to persuade a customer service worker to call his we because he claimed to have found her car keys outside.Michael said his South African we’s first name was “Tess” and she has African double-barrelled surname “Cosis-Chippa”.Giving the alert to the store, she said: “This is a customer announcement.“Can Tess Cosis-Chippa please come to the customer service desk.”Michael, from Swinton, burst out laughing because it sounded like she was admitting that “Tesco’s is cheaper” than Asda.The traffic management worker uploaded the video to his Facebook page and it has since been shared hundreds of times.He told the Manchester Evening News: “I could not stop laughing. I go in there every day for my lunch because Im working on the new tram stop.As we were leaving, this lady shouted at us to come over and we had a laugh about it. I heard excuse me and she came over and shook my hand saying you got me a good one. She found it hilarious.”Michael was able to set up the woman by coming up with an elaborate story about his we’s keys.He told her: “Hi, I’ve just been hopping in your store with my we.“The issue is that we lost a set of car keys. I’ve just come back to the car and found them by the car.“My partner left her phone in the car and I can’t get in touch with her.“I was wonderingyou could give her a quick shout on the tannoy.“Her name is Tess. It’s double barrelled. It’s Cosis-Chippa, it’s South African. OK, thank you very much. Bye.”An Asda spokesman said: As cheeky as this little prank was, when it comes to being cheaper, winning the Grocer  price award for the last  years running is all our customers need to know.

title: esther mcvey running candidate prime minister
story: The ex-Cabinet minister revealed she will put her name forward to replace Theresa May as party leader and PM.And she vowed to reopen talks on Brexit to remove the hated Irish backstop from the existing deal.Ms McVey joins a crowded field of at least  candidates vying to become Prime Minister after Mrs May quits.Askedshe would throw her hat in the ring, she told talkRADIO: Ive always said quite clearly thatI got enough support from colleagues then yes I would, and now people have come forward and I have that support.The former Work and Pensions Secretary praised Mrs May as dutul but insisted its now time for the PM to stand down.She said: It is about the delivery of Brexit, it is about having the team in place that can do that.Youve got to have somebody that actually believes in Brexit. Get rid of that backstop and use the £billion to get that free-trade agreement.You have to have belief in the opportunities of Brexit... you have to believe that the backstop must go, you need a new team of negotiators.Ms McVey quit the Cabinet last year in protest at the withdrawal agreement negotiated by Mrs May.In the leadership race she will go up against other Brexiteers including Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab.Cabinet ministers planning to stand include Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid, Andrea Leadsom, Matt Hancock, Penny Mordaunt and Michael Gove.And other less well-known Tories such as James Cleverly, Mark Harper and Steve Baker are also considering a tilt at No.

title: amazon driver finger chopped off letterbox
story: Husam Aljuburi, , was halfway through his sht for Amazon when he shoved an A package through a door.When he pulled his hand back, the top of his middle finger got trapped in the flap — and was chopped clean off.Frantic Husam flagged down a passerby, who called an ambulance — with the paramedic retrieving the severed fingertip before putting it on an ice block in a plastic bag.Medics were unable to reattach the chopped off appendage, and even had to cut off more of his finger in a  minute operation to sew it all back up properly.Dad-of-one Husam got a taxi back to the house where he lost his finger to pick up the rest of the parcels hed stashed in his nearby car.Traumatised Husam, from Hanger Hill, west London, said he feels like he has lost a part of him and hasnt been able to go back to work due to the pain.Husam said: Im right-handed so my le has been completely changed.PlayStation is going to be a struggle now with the controller.I like playing table tennis too but I suppose thats going to be a lot harder now.SayI meet the woman of my dreams Im always going to be weary now as Im missing a part of me.I know there are people worse off than me and have lost limbs but Im still in shock.Ive made , deliveries so I know what Im doing.It was something like a book or a DVD.It was a slim parcel so decided to put it through the letterbox.I put my hand in with all four fingers intact and then seconds later a quarter of my middle finger was off.To be honest I didnt feel anything but I was screaming like mad.I think it was the shock.I just dont know how it happened and Ive never had anything like this happen to me before.Dad-of-one Husam, who has been a delivery driver for nine months, was delivering his th parcel of the day on April  when the accident happened.With blood spurting from his hand, he took a photo, then grabbed his finger and stopped a passerby who called an ambulance to take him to AE at Wrexham hospital.Husam added: The person wasnt in so I was desperately looking around for someone to help.Luckily this man happened to me walking past.I was hoping for the best but the doctors took one look at it and basically told me there.Its weird. It was such a quick operation for something that has changed my le forever.When he arrived back at the property — four hours after the le-changing incident — Husam found the homeowner scrubbing away his blood on her drive.Husam said: I told her what happened and how her letterbox has destroyed my le but she wasnt having any of it.I didnt just cut my finger off and put it through the letterbox for fun.When Husam phoned Amazon he claims it was shrugged off and was told to email Amazon Flex — the delivery driver firm.Husam also claims he was told tothe undelivered parcels back to the depot ten miles away or risk not getting paid for the sht.Self-employed Husam drove  minutes one-handed back to the west London depot before driving home.Husam, who has to visit his GP every other day to get his dressing change, has been off work ever since.For all those people who think Amazon is great I just want to tell them how they treat their workers.A spokesman for Amazon said: Safety is Amazons number one priority.We continue to be in close contact with the driver, wish him a speedy recovery and are sorry that he feels we did not handle the matter correctly.We have investigated the matter and will take appropriate action.

story: Chilling footage of the robbery went viral and was shared by the Britains Got Taken judge who urged the public to call the policeyou know these scumbags.The thugs were chased away by builders brandishing scaffolding poles after they spotted them demanding the mum hand over her jewellery in Richmond, South West London.Witnesses told The Sun Online they heard a mum screaming “don’t take my baby” during the terrying incident in June last year.But by the time she had made her way down to the road the attackers had made their escape.She said: “We were at home and heard a woman shouting ‘my baby, don’t take my baby’.“At first I thought it was just road rage but the road was soon cordoned off and full of police.“It was obvious that it was something more serious and we’ve now seen the CCTV assault and robbery.The -strong group, three of whom have no previous convictions, was also behind a string of high profile raids across London, including stealing £, of camera equipment used to film the Oxford and Cambridge boat race.The thugs, aged between  and , and who were all linked to ringleader Marsh today appeared at Kingston crown court for  offences.These included conspiracy to rob, conspiracy to burgle, conspiracy to steal, criminal damage and handling stolen goods.Prosecutor Paul Fairley described the gangs history of offending on the second day of the sentencing which was attended by dozens of family members and friends.Worst was Steven Weller, , who had  separate court sentencings for  offences.Ringleader Marsh faces years behind bars after amassing  appearances for  offences including burglaries from  to .The gang first came to attention on New Years Eve  after a ram raid on outdoor clothing company Altimus Ltd in Kensington using a stolen Range Rover and several mopeds.Three were arrested last May after a high-speed police chase which lasted more than  minutes and spanned ten London boroughs.The trio, who were piled on the same moped and drove the wrong way up the A, tried to film their escape attempt.Omar Tafat, , of Fulham, west London, admitted theft, going equipped to steal, criminal damage to a police car and breach of a criminal behaviour order, and was found guilty of two further counts of robbery and possession of an offensive weapon at trial.Josh Myers, , of Shepherds Bush, west London, pleaded guilty to attempted theft, going equipped to steal, criminal damage to a police car, dangerous driving, driving whilst disqualied, possession of an offensive weapon and conspiracy to steal.He was also found guilty of two further counts of robbery and possession of an offensive weapon at trial.Kian Taylor, , admitted attempted theft, going equipped to steal, criminal damage to a police car, dangerous driving, driving whilst disqualied pleaded guilty to conspiracy to rob, conspiracy to steal and conspiracy to burgle.Ryan Moran, , of Fulham, admitted conspiracy to steal, conspiracy to burgle and handling stolen goods.John McFadyen, of Feltham, west London, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to rob, while his brother Isaac, , admitted conspiracy to rob.Mitchall Leaver, , of Battersea, south west London, admitted conspiracy to burgle. His twin brother Scott, of Lambeth, was found guilty of the same charge after trial.Aaron Pask, , of White City, west London, was convicted of conspiracy to burgle and conspiracy to steal, while Ram Monk , of no fixed address was found guilty of conspiracy to burgle.The sentencing hearing continues and is expected to conclude on Monday.

title: labour brexit second referendum
story: The leftie leader admitted he cannot ignore the vote for Brexit and suggested it would be undemocratic to stay in.Mr Corbyns intervention comes as a blow to Labour figures who are keen for the party to back a second referendum.Hours before the leaders speech, the man running Labours Euro elections campaign insisted a vote for the party was a vote to reverse Brexit.But Mr Corbyn said: Over million people voted to leave the European Union. As democratic socialists, we cannot ignore that.We voted to trigger Article  in  and promised to respect the referendum in our general election manesto and again at our party conference last year.He also admitted Brexit has seen Britain stuck in this endless loop with Remainers pitted against Leavers.Speaking at the Labour manesto launch in Kent, the party leader warned that cross-party talks to get a Brexit deal are on the brink of collapse.He said: So far in those talks, there has been no big offer, and the red lines remain.It’s dficult negotiating with a disintegrating government with Cabinet ministers jockeying for the succession, rather than working for an agreement.Lib Dem MP Tom Brake blasted: It is clear that Jeremy Corbyn has trashed the hopes of Remainers.Labour have been sitting on the fence while locked in talks with the Tories to try and forge a compromise agreement.But MEP Richard Corbett, whos in charge of Labours Euro elections campaign, this morning claimed that a vote for the party is a vote for a second referendum on Brexit.He told the BBC: If the Government thinks its deal is so good, they should put it to the people in another referendum.Asked whether he would still demand a referendumthe cross-party talks produced a reply, Mr Corbett said: Thats very hypothetical because the Governments just not going to move to that position is it.Theresa May cant move an inch without her party destroying her on that, they wont accept any movement.Its costing a fortune, its a mess this Brexit, and that is what we want the opportunity to put to the people to reject.The Lib Dems are also launching their own manesto today under the slogan B*****ks to Brexit.Leader Vince Cable said: Brexit is a failed project, which must now be stopped so our country and the whole of Europe can get on with dealing with the big challenges we face.Theresa May wants to hold a fourth vote on her deal before next Thursdays polls.Justice Secretary David Gauke said today: If we are in a position to win a vote, we’ll bring it back as soon as possible.Nigel Farages Brexit Party is expected to come top in the European Parliament elections.

title: royal baby pictures you missed
story: Royal baby pictures you may have missed as Meghan and Harry show Archie to the worldMeghan Markle and Prince Harry couldnt have looked prouder as they gave the world the first glimpse of their new baby boy, Archie Harrison Mountbatten-WindsorShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews ReporterBilly Labrum:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry waited two days until they introduced their little bundle of joy to the world - deciding against the traditional reveal outside hospital and instead opting for a photocall in St Georges Hall at Windsor Castle in Berkshire yesterday. The world has waited excitedly to meet Meghan Markle and Prince Harrys new baby boy - Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor.Archie was born on Monday at .am, weighing lb oz, but the Duke and Duchess of Sussex chose to spend the first couple of days with him in private. As the new parents eventually posed with their son yesterday in St Georges Hall at Windsor Castle, they couldnt contain their joy.They spoke of their first moments with Archie as "amazing" and "special" and said they were thrilled to have their own little bundle of joy. Harry cradled Archie, wrapped in a white blanket, as a supportive Meghan put her arm around them and looked dotingly at her two best guys in the world. Here are all the best photos of the new family-of-three. The first glimpse of Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor who was born on Monday at .am, and was thought to be about a week overdue.  of The Queen and Prince Philip beamed as they met their eighth great-grandchild for the first time, along with Meghans mum Doria Ragland who looked every inch the doting gran as she peered over daughter s shoulder and gazed lovingly at her new grandson.  of Appearing for the first time after giving birth, the Duchess of Sussex wore a white dress from designer Grace Wales Bonner, who has a British mother and Jamaican father.  of Meghan told how her son has the sweetest temperament and that hes really calm - to which Harry replied I dont know who he gets that from, sending them both into giggles.  of The former actress appeared in awe of little Archie and said hes just been the dream, so its been a special couple of days.  of Meghan said they are still trying to figure out who he takes after, with Harry adding that his looks are changing every single day, so who knows.  of The glowing Duchess said she felt happy to have the best two guys in the whole world and could not hide her joy.  of The -year-old former Suits actress is used to the limelight - but many thought even she looked a little nervous as the new family faced the worlds media.  of A small press pool of only one reporter, one photographer and three cameramen were present along with the couples own private photographer and a household press officer photographer.  of The tot made his debut wrapped in a white merino wool shawl and white cashmere hat, knitted by a small, family-run company which was also used by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge for their children.  of Harry, dressed in a light grey suit, cradled his son who was tucked up in the hand-finished shawl made by the Nottingham company GH Hurt  Son, based in Chilwell.  of Meghan wore a gold and turquoise gem necklace by Jen Meyer and earrings by Adina Reyter. Turquoise is regarded as the love charm and is also a symbol of good fortune and success - maybe hinting at her love and hopes for health and happiness for her son.  of The press were told they had just  seconds to get their photos and a reporter could then ask three questions, however, the Duke and Duchess didnt rush them along and in the end the whole thing lasted three minutes.  of Meghan and Harry had wanted to take the photos on the steps behind Windsor Castle, in the same spot they posed for one of their official wedding pictures, but typical British weather meant this wasnt possible.  of Archie is seventh in line to the throne, the Queen and the Duke of Edinburghs eighth great-grandchild and the Prince of Waless fourth grandchild.  of Meghan has been praised by women around the world for helping to normalise how a new mums stomach looks after childbirth by not hiding her bump. of Meghan and Harry revealed the babys name just a few hours after meeting the press. They have to tell the Queen before its officially announced, so its likely they did this when they met her and Prince Philip afterwards.  of Prince Harry proved hes going to be a hands on dad by breaking tradition of the new mum holding the baby for the first photoshoot.  of Meghan thanked everybody for all the well wishes and kindness and said it meant a lot to them as a couple.  of The Duchess of Sussex put a loving arm around her husband as they walked away after they faced the cameras for the first time together following the birth of their baby.  of More OnArchie Harrison Mountbatten-WindsorMeghan MarklePrince HarryRoyal FamilyBabiesCommentsShow more comments

story: NewsEnglands inequality map REVEALED: Search to see full figures for your areaEXCLUSIVE: Devastating new figures lay bare a North-South ide over education, health and living standards - with some workers earning £. an hour more than othersShareCommentsByAnnie Gouk:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsNew data reveals a north south ide in inequality "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNorth East workers earn £. an hour less than their counterparts in the South East, a damning study reveals today. The report by England’s human rights watchdog lays bare a North-South ide over inequality - with a postcode lottery in education, health, employment and living standards. The report “Is England Fairer ” is from the Equality and Human Rights Commission, and was shared exclusively with the Mirror’s Data Unit. It shows that those living in the North East are particularly badly off, while those in the South East have the best le chances in the country - even out-performing London. The report finds that the unemployment rate in the North Eastis now nearly twice as high as it is in the South East . Nearly a third of workers in the North East are in low-paid workcompared to just a quarter of those in the South East .        And people in the South East earn £. more an hour on average than they do in the North East - with median hourly earnings of £. compared to £.. That means % of all children in the North East are currently living in poverty, compared to just % of children in the South East. Caroline Waters, deputy chair of the EHRC, said: “We are living in an increasingly ided society. “As the country grapples with Brexit , it’s more important than ever that we address the fractures in our society and ensure opportunities are shared fairly across the country. The report found a quarter of adults in the North Eastexperience severe material deprivation, compared to one in every six in the South East . Meanwhile, one in every three adults in the North East report poor health , compared to a fth of those in the South East .  People in the North West and the West Midlands are also often worse off than those living in the rest of the country. And while London beat the South East in some areas, such as earnings, the capital also has the highest proportion of people working in insecure jobs, and particularly high levels of poverty and poor health. The report compared  dferent data sets to put together a ranking of inequality. Ms Waters said: “Where you grow up should not determine your outcome in le.  “We’re seeing an increasing push to devolve power and build better infrastructure outside London. Local Mayors, councils, charities and businesses are uniquely placed to ensure that this is fair growth and doesn’t leave anyone behind. “Equality across England isn’t out of reach but dferent regions must work with and not against each other. “Organisations in all areas of England have something to share and by combining their experience and expertise, we have a much better chance of improving le outcomes for everyone, no matter where they live.” Shadow Cabinet Office minister Jon Trickett said: This report lays bare the striking regional inequality that ides England, but which all-too-often gets left out of the national conversation. “For generations the North of England has been held back by Tory elites that have failed to invest, that have made decisions in the interest of the wealthy and powerful, and that have bodged regional devolution. A Government spokesperson said: “Creating opportunity across the UK will always be our priority, which is why we are investing £m over three years to deliver better educational outcomes and le chances in some of the most deprived areas. “We have also committed over £ billion through devolution and growth deals, helping further empower local people to make the key decisions that affect their lives.”

story: NewsGrenfell: Tories FINALLY unveil £m for cladding to stop another catastropheMinisters stepped in with the pot for  buildings after almost two years of disputes between building owners and the governmentShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPreviously the government said it was for private developers to fund the repairs after the fire at Grenfell Tower "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers have been hailed for finally unveiling £million to stop another Grenfell - almost two years after the fatal tower block fire. The government stepped in to remove unsafe building aposcladdingapos, like that used on the West London block, from  privately-owned high-rises across the UK. Previously the government said it was for private developers to fund the repairs themselves. But dozens of freeholders and developers refused to pay to make their own blocks safe, leaving , people in limbo. Campaigners today welcomed the cash but slammed the government for taking almost two years to announce it after the blaze that killed  people. Grenfell United, a group of survivors and the bereaved, said it offered hope to people feeling at risk at home. But Polly Neate, chief executive of housing charity Shelter, said: It is a source of deep concern that, nearly two years after the devastating Grenfell fire, this dangerous cladding is still on buildings.    It is vital that it is removed as quickly as possible. The first priority of any government must be to protect its citizens, so we welcome todayaposs announcement. We look forward to seeing more detail on the scheme and hope it is able to work quickly and effectively to give residents a safe home. Chartered Institute of Housing chief executive Terrie Alafat said: Almost two years since the Grenfell Tower tragedy, it is quite frankly unacceptable that so many private tower blocks have been left with dangerous cladding, leaving thousands of people living in fear.Together with Inside Housing and many other organisations we have been calling on the government to end this scandal now - so todayaposs announcement from the Prime Minister is very welcome. Labour ’s Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey said: “It is welcome that the Government is finally giving some help to worried residents in private blocks with Grenfell-style cladding. But it is astonishing that it has taken Ministers almost two years to act. “The Government must now back the further steps Labour has been calling for, and set a deadline to make all blocks safe.” Lord Porter, Chairman of the councilsapos body the Local Government Association, said he had been lobbying for action since .    The Tory peer said: “This announcement will come as an enormous relief to leaseholders who are in no way to blame for the dangerous cladding on their homes. They have suffered for far too long. The money will be made available to remove aluminium composite material cladding from around  privately owned high-rise buildings across the UK. Building owners will have three months to claim the funds, with one condition being that they take reasonable steps to recover the costs from those responsible for the claddingaposs presence. Prime Minister Theresa May said: It is of paramount importance that everybody is able to feel and be safe in their homes. Thataposs why we asked building owners in the private sector to take action and make sure appropriate safety measures were in place. And weaposve seen a number of private building owners doing the right thing and taking responsibility, but unfortunately too many are continuing to pass on the costs of removal and replacement to leaseholders. Today I can confirm we will now be fully funding the replacement of cladding on high-rise private residential buildings so residents can feel confident they are secure in their homes. A spokesperson for the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government toldis why the lack of action by some private building owners was “completely unacceptable”. They added: “Due to lack of progress the government is looking at a range of new additional measures to get building owners to do the right thing.” Last week, the housing minister Kit Malthouse said: “We have been engaged across government to consider additional interventions, so that progress can be made more swtly.” He said he hoped to announce specic measures shortly. The department insists leaseholders were currently protected from remediation costs in  out of  residential buildings. “The growing list of owners and developers who have stepped in includes Barratt Developments, Mace Group, Legal  General, Peabody, Aberdeen Asset Management and Frasers Property,” he said. “In the social sector we are making good progress,” he added. “In the private sector, progress is slower I absolutely admit that. “We need to do something to speed that up, and we hope to increase the pace quite soon. Discussions are ongoing.

Johnny Mercer said he will no longer back government laws in the Commons - except for, erm, on Brexit - in a bombshell letter to the Prime Minister. The Plymouth Moor View MP, a former Army officer, said his decision was about the prosecution of veterans from Northern Ireland, Afghanistan and Iraq. But he also hit out at the alleged behaviour of Tory Deputy Chief Whip Chris Pincher and claimed recent behaviour of the whips forced my hand. He accused the party machine of a total loss of integrity and a breakdown of the normal way of doing things.” He added: The whipsapos office, the deputy chief whip, attempted to blackmail me into voting for the Prime Minister’s deal by going round some of my old colleagues in the military and trying to seethere were any stories they could use as leverage against me.”    There is no suggestion any Tory whips found incriminating evidence about Mr Mercer. And his aposstrikeapos is likely to have little actual effect, as there is almost no contentious non-Brexit legislation going through the Commons. He was accused of sulking in an interview with BBC Radio aposs Today programme. But he insisted: “My ethos and values may be slowly but very firmly separating from this government. There’s nothing loyal about watching the car go over the clf and not doing anything about it. The incident exposes how the Tory infighting has billowed beyond old guard, hard Brexiteers into newer, younger members of the party.    In his letter, -year-old Mr Mercer hit out at the historical prosecutions of ex-servicemen and women. Supporters say such probes are a natural and right part of the legal system, and can right wrongs of wars. But Mr Mercer claimed there is “usually no evidence at all” and said the government “singularly failed to act for four years now and I’m simply not prepared to put up with it any more.” He said he was not to prepared to vote for government legislation - except on Brexit - before clear and concrete steps to end the abhorrent process.  Mr Mercer has campaigned against the pursuit of legacy cases from the conflicts in Northern Ireland, Afghanistan and Iraq since he entered Parliament in . However, he has also alleged party whips tried to dig up information on his military past to blackmail him for backing Theresa Mayaposs legislation. He wrote in his letter: It has not been an easy decision to make. But this incident with your chief whip has forced my hand. It appears that my values and ethos may be slowly, but very firmly, separating from a party I joined in .

title: britains secret links dozens worlds
story: NewsBritains secret links to dozens of the worlds top leaders revealedNew figures released by the Foreign Office show that  current world leaders were educated at British institutions.ShareCommentsBySteve MyallDeputy Features Editor:,  MAY NewsBritains education system is the envy of the world "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain might be a small island about to cut itself adrt from the rest of Europe but its place in the world is a giant one. And it has now been revealed that the UK has unknown links to dozens of the globeaposs top leaders thanks to its world class education system. The reach of the United Kingdomaposs schools, colleges and universities stretches right around the world and new figures, released by the Foreign Office, show  current world leaders were educated at British institutions. Among the names are both the Iraq and Iran Presidents and a host of African leaders. And itaposs not all Oxford and Cambridge University, Salford and Bristol have played their parts as well as Brentford University which was attended by the President of Sierra Leone. Last week Japanese Emperor Naruhito succeeded his father but as a young man he attended Merton College, Oxford, where his thesis was A Study of Navigation and Traffic on the Upper Thames in the th Century. Speaking on Radio , Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the widespread attendance of world leaders at British education establishments was an example of soft power. Hereaposs the full list of world leaders and were they went to be educated in Britain.  President of Ireland, Michael Higgins attended the University of Manchester. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban studied political science at Pembroke College, Oxford. King of Norway Harald V went to Balliol College, Oxford where he studied history, economics and politics.  He was a keen rower during his student days at Oxford and was taught to row by fellow student and friend Nick Bevan, later a leading British school rowing coach. King of Belgium Philippe I went to Trinity College, Oxford. President of Iceland Guðni Thorlacius Jóhannesson  earned a degree in history and political science from the University of Warwick and a degree in history from St Antonyaposs College, Oxford. The Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat went to Bristol University. Prince Albert of Monaco went to Bristol University.  Queen of Denmark Margrethe II went to Cambridge University and the London School of Economics. The President of Cyprus Nicos Anastasiades went to the University of London. King of the Netherlands Willem-Alexander went to UWC Atlantic College, in WalesAsia  Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan attended Oxford University. King of Bhutan Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck went to Oxford University. Burmese State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi went to Oxford University Prime Minister of Singapore Lee Hsien Loong went to Cambridge University The Sultan of Brunei, Hassanal Bolkiah, went to Sandhurst Royal Military Academy The King of Thailand Maha Vajiralongkorn attended Millfield School. The King of Malaysia, Sultan Abdullah, was sent to Aldenham School, in Elstree, and then to Sandhurst Emperor Naruhito of Japan went to Oxford University Middle East King Abdullah II of Jordan went to St Edmund’s School, in Hindhead, and Sandhurst and Oxford University. The President of Egypt Abdelfateh al-Sisi attended the military institution the Joint Services Command and Staff College, in Shrivenham. Iraqi President Barham Salih went to Cardf University and Liverpool University. The other time, I chose a typical male thing, he adds. I donapost know why. I am joining millions around the UK and beyond by fasting from dawn until sunset every night for a month, and documenting my experience below as I go. Fasting, or apossawmapos as itaposs known in Arabic, is one of the five pillars of Islam. By giving up food, we think about those who are less fortunate than ourselves, and may not know when their next meal will come. But itaposs not just about food, itaposs about being grateful and appreciating all the things you have. For me, it has always been a way to realign myself with my faith every year.Some days I find myself feeling more focused, mindful and at peace. I feel the benefits, I see the purpose of it and I even enjoy it, telling myself I might just fast on random days during the year to ground myself.  But other days I feel I canapost cope, my stomach grumbles, I consider giving up, I feel void of energy and Iaposve had enough. For the next month, Iaposm going to blog my experience to lt the lid on what fasting is really like - see below for my post on Day Four.  Being as honest as I can be, I will write about my highs, my lows and everything in between. Iaposll also aim to answer all those questions youaposve probably never dared ask. To start with a few: No youaposre not allowed to drink water, yes you can brush your teeth, no I donapost believe it is harmful to your healthitaposs done sensibly , no you canapost just eat something and aposnot tell anyoneapos and yes you can swallow your own saliva...  May : Challenges Iaposm facing with fasting as I reach Day FourI’m on day four of fasting and so far, I’m fine without food, and I’m fine without water. But what I am really struggling with is the lack of caffeine.Like many, I rely on a cup of tea or coffee to give me a boost in the morning to help me work, focus, and perk me up in general.I woke up on Monday, the first day of Ramadan, with a pounding headache and knewI could just have even a sip of coffee it would have been fixed. But alas, I powered through and the pounding head soon disappeared as the day went on. What I’ve also realised is how much we use food and drink for comfort.Filling our bellies is not just about sustenance. Our meals and hot drinks affect us emotionally and give our moods a boost. Without that bit of sugar, or whatever  it is you crave, we have to find inner strength to give us that push.  Something  I’ve done, which I’m not sure I should have, is calculate the number of hours I’m fasting.Using the official dawn and sunset times for London todayI will be fasting for a total of more than  hours.That leaves me with under seven hours to try and fit in three balanced meals and two pints of water while striving for the recommended eight hours sleep - an impossible task. So instead I have to weigh things up and decide what to compromise on - food, water or sleep  Generally I prioritise water as I know how important it is to be hydrated, I try and get in two meals as any more would make me feel sick in such a short space of time, and aim to sleep for six hours, but itaposs certainly a squeeze.   May : Ramadan is imminent and I feel totally unprepared Ramadan begins on Monday, and I feel totally unprepared. The truth is, thereaposs no way to get yourself ready mentally - it seems to just come around really quickly every year and you just have to get on with it. Iaposve written a checklist - or shopping list - of what I need to get beforehand. Dates come top of the list as Muslims break their fast with dates every night. Itaposs a tradition that goes back to the Prophet Mohammed, and the high levels of sugar are a great way to boost your energy having not eaten for hours. Iaposm going to hit Tesco and make sure my fridge is well stocked for the night times. Then Iaposll have a huge feast, drink lots of water and go to bed ready for the challenge to begin.  When is Ramadan  It is the ninth month in the Islamic calendar, which is determined by the lunar cycle. When it starts is based on the sighting of the new moon, which marks the beginning of the month. If the new moonis spotted, fasting begins the following day. Similarly when determining the last day of Ramadan,the new moon is sighted the holy month is complete and Eid is celebrated the following day. Local sightings of the moon can dfer, which is why there can be discrepancies between the days dferent countries start and end their fast. It moves about  days each year in the Gregorian calendar, which is based on the solar year. Ramadan can last either  or  days. This year it began on Monday May .

story: NewsTracked down after  years - the miracle baby found in the Morpeth train wreckExpress sleeper crashed at mph on our most notorious railway bend - but somehow little Colin Garness survivedShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  MAY NewsNurse holds tiny survivor Colin Garness "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCradled in a nurse’s arms, peacefully sucking on a bottle, blue-eyed baby Colin Garness was the ray of light in a dark, disaster story. Hours earlier, on May , , an express sleeper crashed at mph on our most notorious railway bend. Six died and  were injured, including Colin’s parents. But, incredibly, their seven-month-old son escaped death by inches – with just one scratch on his forehead. Firemen pulled him from the mangled compartment and took him to hospital for a check-up. The following day the Daily Mirror introduced the world to “The Miracle Baby Found In The Train Wreck.”    Now  years old, Colin Garness says: “I count myself incredibly lucky to have survived.” Speaking after we tracked him down half a century later, he adds: “We’d been in a sleeper compartment, dad on the top bunk, mum and me below. During the night I woke crying, and mum moved me to the end of the bed. “She always saidshe hadn’t done that I could have been crushed to death – and she counts her blessings.” The accident, which would prove a landmark in railway safety, happened at around .am as the train from London King’s Cross to Aberdeen sped north through Northumberland.    It all went wrong on the infamous “Morpeth Curve” where the railway line turns back on itself at  degrees – the tightest bend in Britain. Five people were killed when a train derailed there in  and the stretch had a mph limit. On the morning of the  crash The Aberdonian Express entered the curve at more than twice the limit after the driver lost concentration. He braked too late and the  carriages careered off the track.  Two shot up the embankment, another was speared by a section of rail. The Mirror’s report the next day on the “Nightmare on a sleeper express” told how dazed ­passengers escaped. A hero doctor, himself hurt, tended to the injured and dying before collapsing. Eleven fire crews battled to free those who were trapped – including the Garness family. Colin Senior, then , a mechanic in the Fleet Air Arm, and we Jackie, , were ing home to Lossiemouth, Scotland, after taking their son to see Jackie’s parents in Nottingham. Colin Junior, , now lives in Dundee with we Anne and children Emily, , Elizabeth, , and Murray, .  Colin, who works as an operations supervisor on an offshore oil , explains: “I knew about what happened from a very early age, because my parents wanted to tell me how lucky I’d been. “They’d picked up the Aberdonian Express in Grantham, settled into the sleeper compartment and gone off to sleep at about pm. “Suddenly they were upside down and being thrown about. It must have been terrying. “Mum was trapped, but because she had moved me in the night I escaped. Dad broke his shoulder. I don’t know whether it was when he was trying to break the door to get them all out. “Eventually people came and cut a hole in the cabin door and my dad managed to hand me out to them. “I was carried off to a family who lived nearby, who very kindly looked after me until I was taken to hospital to be checked over. I was completely unharmed – just a bump on my head.”  As Colin was rushed to Newcastle upon Tyne, his mum Jackie was still trapped. “She had to be cut out by the fire service,” he says. “She’d injured her back and has suffered back pain as a result.” When Jackie was freed she was loaded into one of  ambulances on scene. Colin’s parents were taken to Ashington Hospital –  miles away from their baby son. Staff reassured them little Colin was doing fine and next morning the Daily Mirror’s front page showed him happily taking a bottle from a nurse. Later that day his dad was well enough to visit him, reporting to Jackie he was “looking chirpy”. It was another  hours before Jackie was reunited with her baby, after two nurses took him to her. And the Mirror was there to capture the moment with our reporter writing: “Jackie cried with relief when he was gently placed beside her on the pillow.” A full inquiry was carried out by Colonel JRH Robertson, Permanent Secretary to the EnvironmentDepartment. He found the driver, Leslie Byers, , solely responsible.He said he failed to brake as he was worrying about a letter from bosses asking him to explain why he was four minutes late on a earlier run. The Colonel wrote: “Driver Byers relaxed his customary concentration and allowed his mind to become distracted.” But he added: “I was much impressed by Driver Byers. “He struck me as a very good type of driver and a careful and conscientious man. He did not seek to excuse himself in any way.” He said the driver had attached too much importance to the routine notice and taken “the implied criticism too much to heart”. In  British Rail began putting floodlit warnings carrying the speed limit well before braking points. They were dubbed “Morpeth boards”.  But technical issues meant they weren’t put on the curve itself until  when a sleeper derailed at the same spot, injuring . story: NewsWoman, , allergic to WATER is left in burning pain from a single dropA single drop of water can cause Niah Selway an intense burning all over her body that will last for hoursShareCommentsByFederico CornettoKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAY NewsNiah Selway has spoken about her daily struggle "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman with an extremely rare allergy to water has revealed the tragic struggle of her day-to-day le. Niah Selway has such severe reactions that a single drop of water can cause an intense burning all over her body that will last for hours. The -year-old has Aquagenic Pruritus, an allergy that only affects very few people worldwide and has no known cause. The rare condition means that, even though Niahaposs organs are not affected and she can still drink water, liquids cannot come into contact with her skin. And everything from her own tears to sweat and urine can trigger allergic reactions. Niah, from Hastings, East Sussex, has symptoms so intense that she will often fall-asleep from exhaustion after a reaction, and has been left housebound.    Despite being under specialists for nearly four years, medical professionals are yet to find out the cause. Niah, who is known on YouTube as the aposGirl whoaposs allergic to waterapos, said: I am suffering in a really severe way, and no medication or treatment has had any substantial effect. It doesnapost matter where the water touches me,a drop touches my arm the pain will spread to my back and torso, sometimes to my whole body. When I have a bath my whole body burns for hours on end. Over time I worked out a routine, either way itaposs painful but I have found ways to make it a little less traumatic. It is basically a disability because of the things I can no longer do.    In the morning I get to the toilet and Iaposll have an allergic reaction to the first thing I do. I also canapost do much exercise apart from yoga and walking because I canapost sweat, and on hot days Iaposll have to be stuck in front of the fan. My day is working around my pain. Niah experienced her first reactions at the age of five, with them worsening through puberty and finally peaking over the last couple of years. Towards the beginning of , Niah came to the realisation that her illness would not allow her to lead a normal le. She credits her strength to her parents Bob and Antonia and boyfriend Mark.
