Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: Marianne Taylor   Cybernats    and extremists represent the worst of times
story: Written in , harking back to Francersquos Reign of Terror, it is also a sobering reminder of what can happen when nuance is removed from public discourse. And unfortunately, dear reader, there is much to worry about these days on that score.Read more: SNP declares war on cybernatsNowhere do we see it more than on social media. With this in mind, I applaud unequivocal attempts by prominent SNP figures, as outlined in yesterdayrsquos Herald, to denounce the online abuse spat out by some on their side of the constitutional debate, not just at opponents of independence, but anyone who dares say or tweet something, no matter how innocuous, that doesnrsquot chime entirely with their world view. Describing such keyboard warriors as ldquoweird, ldquocreepy, ldquopoisonous, ldquovicious ldquocowards, former party deputy Angus Robertson, MP Stewart McDonald and MEP Alyn Smith are absolutely right to point out that such trolling, bullying and harassment ndash much of it aimed specically at women ndash is not only out of order, but ultimately damaging to the cause they support.If anyone is in any doubt about the form this sort of intimidation takes, you need only look at last weekrsquos bullying of BBC Scotland journalist Emma Clford Bell. Researching a piece about Dundeersquos reaction to Nicolarsquos Sturgeonrsquos announcement on a possible second independence referendum, she did her job and appealed on social media for a pro-Union voice to appear among a ldquoiety of opinions ndash including pro-independence supporters ndash to be featured in the package. What followed was a pile-on of epic and bizarre proportions, as hundreds jumped on the bandwagon and accused her of bias, told her to ldquof*** off , that she was ldquoscum, a ldquoclown of a lassie and a ldquostupid bint.Primarily, this is a very personal ndash not to mention sexist ndash attack on Ms Clford Bell. But it also represents a worrying and increasingly common assault on the act and process of journalism itself, a wilful misunderstanding of what journalists do, a knowing conflation of news and comment, a perpetuation of the warped idea that ldquogood journalism is what I agree with, and ldquobad journalism is everything .Read more: SNP declares war on cybernatsMore than anything, it reflects a worrying lack of critical thinking. Indeed, some of the responses to those who criticised the bad behaviour are as grim as the initial attack blaming the victim, whatabouteryand reeling off old complaints about BBC presenters only makes it worse. Whorsquod want to share a movement, let alone a country ndash independent or not ndash with these people Ms Clford Bellrsquos experience is a depressing sign of the times that reflects a more general willingness to trade critical thinking for the ease of conspiracy theories, righteous anger, having a , and a sense of identity and community, eventhe latter is based on nothing more than the precarious idea of a shared enemy.At the same time, the power and reach of social media also attracts those looking to monetise certain views, not to mention nefarious organisations and even foreign states whose main aim is to stir up trouble. And since the current system encourages anonymity and duplicity, it can be hard to work out who or what is even real.The so-called lsquoCybernatsrsquo exist in a relatively tiny corner of social media, of course, their vitriol matched by those shouting about other extreme world views, most notably ldquoBrit Nats, Hard Brexiteers, Trump supporters and white supremacists.Theyrsquore all equally unsavoury, flourishing by using OTT, hysterical narratives to pinpoint and frame their attacks, often choosing to personally abuse the target in the process humiliate, intimidate and crush.Since they shout so loud, the lsquoCybernatsrsquo often succeed in getting the attention they crave, which in turn exaggerates how representative their views are within the Yes movement, thus turning off more moderate supporters and potential new recruits to the cause.Depressingly, thatrsquos why I think it will be so dficult for Messrs Robertson, McDonald and Smith to change anything. The attack dogs do so knowingly, in order to deliberately provoke attention, or are so far down the unthinking zealot road as to be beyond reach. What both have in common is that the more they insult, the easier it becomes.Such abuse has nothingto do with independence per se, but the damage for the wider Yes movement will be harder to disassociate.The appeal for nuance and persuasion comes at a time when both seem out of fashion, while extreme language pulses and trends through our discourse.Those of us looking for comfort should perhaps turn back to Dickens. At the very least, A Tale of Two Cities reminds us that nothing ndash not even the worst of times - lasts forever.

title: johann-lamont-on-20-years-of-devolution-labour-went-from-56-msps-to-23
story: Among the first crop of MSPs to be elected to the Scottish Parliament, Johann Lamont remembers the excitement and fearlessness of those early days.A teacher with young children of her own, the former Scottish Labour leader hadnt expected to become a politician, but felt a strong sense of being part of something "really important".She still recalls the shock, then, when that atmosphere of heady opportunity gave way "almost immediately" to negative headlines and relentless scrutiny.ldquoIt felt both very exciting, very challenging, that sense of uncertainty in any new job, but then combined with almost a backlash," she says. "We were naive and didnrsquot really see it coming.Sitting in her office in Holyrood ndash the pound million complex that inspired so many of those early press stories ndash Ms Lamont reflects on the last two decades of devolution.The Glasgow MSP led Scottish Labour from  to , steering it through one of the most dramatic periods in recent political history.Standing down shortly after the independence referendum, she famously hit out at its London leadership for treating the Scottish party like a "branch office".Now she says she wont run for Holyrood again when the next elections arrive in , though she is a Glasgow South candidate for Westminster.She is brutally honest when it comes to Scottish Labours current fortunes in Holyrood.ldquoThere were  of us [in the beginning] ndash therersquos now ," she says. "That tells its own story."Irsquove personally moved from the centre of the chamber to one side, and Irsquom now up the back on the backbenches of the third party."Soyou wanted a graphic description of whatrsquos happened to the Labour Party, and the challenges we face, therersquos a sense of that."Shes also forthright when it comes to the shortcomings of the parliament itself. It lacks "big thinking", she says, and has lost the untidy energy that characterised its early days.But its not just Holyrood that has lost its ambition ndash its the institutions and bodies around it.A third sector that was previously bursting with ideas and determination now fears to speak out in case its funding is stripped away by vengeful ministers.ldquoI personally think the third sector, in particular, has been very conditioned in a way that they werenrsquot then," Ms Lamont says.ldquoI think therersquos a lot of people, who are all really good people ndash their ambition is less.ldquoBecause they donrsquot want to fall out, so actually they ask for what they think theyrsquoll get.ldquoI think whats happening now [is] worthy of an investigation by somebody, somewhere,people are willing to speak about it.ldquoThird sector organisations are reminded where their funding comes from, and so they donrsquot really push as hard as they might have done in the past.ldquoAnd actually also, people have accepted that Government backbenchers are not going to rebel. So they donrsquot even put them under pressure.She adds: ldquoObviously the SNP are in power. It may have happened anyway.The MSP says there is an attitude among charities and other organisations of " I go out on a limb here, and say something really dficult, there will be consequences in terms of my funding. So I will not be able to do that again."In the early years of Holyrood, there was always a chance the biggest party would lose out at the next election. But with the dominance of the SNP, "you have to accommodate yourself with that realityyou rely on the funding and things like that".The quality of political debate has also been hit. Most debates now, Ms Lamont says, are simply a proxy for something  - namely, the ongoing constitutional battle over independence.Meanwhile, there is an "unhealthy" dynamic that sees ministers rarely fielding questions from their own side, while the co-operative spirit Holyrood was meant to foster hasnt quite survived contact with reality.ldquoI always thought there was a slight naivety about this idea thatyou put people in a circle and say itrsquos a more [representative] parliament, theyre somehow more likely to agree with each other," Ms Lamont says."I donrsquot think so. I think itrsquos actually in some ways more tribal. But itrsquos not tribal around policy mdash itrsquos tribal around what itrsquos a proxy for.She says the balance between the executive and parliament has changed over the years, with almost half of the current SNP group holding ministerial posts.The former Scottish Labour leader advocates a more "mature", cross-party approach. This could see Green MSPs, who helped vote through the minority SNP Governments Budget earlier this year, drafted in as ministers.ldquoIf they stuck somebody like Andy Wightman in to do land reform, into their Cabinet, that would be quite a good trade-off against other things that the Greens might not be able to do," she says.But amid the disappointments, there have been plenty of good times.Ms Lamont looks back fondly on those early days, when anything seemed possible and friendships were forged "in that sense of being under siege".ldquoI mean, it was really good fun," she says. "It was hilarious. I look back with a lot of sadness.ldquoIf yoursquore anywhere for  years, therersquos things that have happened in your own le.ldquoI lost my mother in . Very, very good friends in here who died, across parties.Sparring with Alex Salmond was also a highlight: "I wouldnrsquot put it as my best memory, but I did enjoy locking horns with Alex Salmond, I must say. An argument with an arrogant man, whatrsquos not to like Elsewhere, she speaks movingly of the death of Donald Dewar, the man credited with delivering devolution and Scotlands inaugural first minister.She recalls the "distraught" look on Labour MSP Tom McCabes face when the news broke in October , and the "big Donald Dewar-sized space, empty, in the room"."In a way his greatest legacy was that he established the parliament in such a form that it survived," she says."But he never really got to shape it at all, and you wonder what that would have looked like."She thinks Holyrood often needs to "lighten up", adding: ldquoI think we all could be doing with being mocked a wee bit more.It also needs to grow up as an institution, and leave the endless constitutional paralysis behind."Wersquore only  years old, so the analogy I would draw is with my own kids," she says.ldquoMy kids were very wee, theyrsquore now in early adulthood. Theyrsquove kind of formed their character, theyrsquove got good values, theyrsquore pushing out there and beginning to understand what they want out of le.ldquoI would think the Scottish Parliament needs to get to that point, and the sooner the better."Because therersquos so many really good things that it has done, and so many good things it can do, and so much resource that can be applied in a dferent way.

title: jim-wallace-gains-outweigh-the-mistakes-in-scottish-parliaments-first-two-decades
story: It was an arresting thought. Now, as we look back over  years to the first Scottish Parliamentary election, it is surely unthinkable that we should ever turn the clock back. And in an age when politicians and political institutions are regularly under attack, perhaps one of the most signicant achievements is that our Parliament is so embedded in Scotlandrsquos political landscape.Its achievements go much further than that. One doesnrsquot have to have approved of all the legislation passed since , but the legislative record of the Parliament is impressive compared to what would have been achievedWestminster had continued to find time for only one or two Scottish measures in a year.Within weeks, the new Parliament had passed the Mental Health Act to plug a signicant legal loophole. It undertook long overdue legislation on land reform. It implemented a host of outstanding Scottish Law Commission proposals.We created National Parks. We opened new railway lines. We provided a Freedom of Information regime, more open and robust than applies to UK public bodies.We led the way in the UK in effecting a ban on smoking in public places. Scotland continues to lead the way in promoting a presumption against very short prison sentences.Moreover, the experience of many who seek to lobby or simply have their voices heard, is that government, ministers and officials, are much closer and more accessible.I recall a visit to Barcelona in the early s, when Scotlandrsquos business community was generally still hostile to any kind of devolution. Something may have been gained in the translation, but our Catalan business hosts said that one of their perceived advantages of devolved government was that ldquothe bums were closer to kick. Many Scottish Ministers over the last  years may attest to that.Notwithstanding achievements, from the Parliamentrsquos earliest days, we had to cope with brickbats and criticism. Perhaps we oversold what could be achieved ndash or at least the time it would take to make a dference. The reality was that neither the Parliament nor the Government took over full legislative and executive powers until st July ndash almost two months after the election.During that time, we scored own goals like minting medals, but some housekeeping was essential. Without fixing allowances, our staff couldnrsquot be paid. But the perception was one of self-serving MSPs, no better than their Westminster counterparts. And the building project dogged us for at least five years, even although the plan and contract had been inherited from Westminster.One of the early controversies was the decision to repeal ldquosection A, which forbade teaching of homosexuality in schools. Having been in the Commons when this particularly pernicious piece of legislation was originally passed, I had no doubt that it was right to end it. But repeal had not been mentioned in either coalition partyrsquos manesto, and the announcement without preparing the ground, nor engaging in prior consultation broke our own rules about the importance of consultation in policy making.Some might argue that in other policy areas, there was too much consultation, which made politics boring but on an issue such as the right of responsible access to land, I believe that extensive discussion with interested parties brought about a well- balanced piece of legislation, which has stood the test of time.I firmly believed that Parliamentrsquos Committees had a crucial role to play, both in holding Ministers to account and in scrutinising legislation. My experience in the first years of the Parliament was that Committees were influential and effective. I had to bring in a Bill to add a religion question to the  Census, after the Equal Opportunities Committeeturned me over when I tried to defend a cabinet decision not to include such a question. My perception, and what I hear from current Parliamentarians, is that the SNPrsquos well acclaimed discipline has robbed Committees of much of their robustness in challenging the administration. Going forward, it is to be hoped that Committees will rediscover their earlier zeal for effective scrutiny.Looking back  years, I recall an election campaign where we discussed issues of everyday importance to Scotlandrsquos people over a wide range of important domestic areas, where the new Parliament had powers. It was a refreshing change from the many general elections Irsquod fought, where the constitutional question dominated, evenit wasnrsquot ranked high in polls identying votersrsquo concerns. Regrettably, more recent election campaigns have reverted to debates about our constitutional future ndash and Irsquom not holding my breath that  will be any dferent.This is regrettable. By comparison with many devolved Parliaments and even states in federal countries, the powers of the Scottish Parliament are extensive, having been considerably added to since . Would it not be more productiveas much energy was given to addressing issues such as Scotlandrsquos demographic challenge, the implications for the future of work in an age of Articial Intelligence, the growing threat of climate change, the need to reverse centralisation and breathe new le into urban, rural and island communities There is no shortage of issues where using the Parliamentrsquos powers, promoting new thinking and making progress by seeking consensus across political ides can bring real benefits to the common wealth of Scotland in the next twenty years.Lord Wallace of Tankerness was the LibDem Deputy First Minister from  to

title: why-some-are-seeing-red-over-the-costs-of-going-green
story: As it extols the virtues of outdoor yoga and mindfulness as ways to soothe the modern soul, the tourist body is showing how to be fully ldquoon trend with the times. When it comes to Scotland today, it seems you can have any colour of policy you want, as long as it is green.Things certainly move fast in the new, greener Scotland. A week and a half ago, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon used her speech at the SNP conference to declare a ldquoclimate emergency. This followed meetings with young climate change campaigners who had gone on strike from school to get across the message that adults were ruining the planet. Scotland was already a world leader in tackling climate change, said the FM, and having announced an emergency she pledged that Scotland would live up to its responsibility to tackle it.Act now or risk devastationThis week, in what was punted as a measure of her dedication, she dumped a manesto commitment to cut air passenger duty. Straight into the grey bin it went, no plans to recycle. Farewell concerns about Scotlandrsquos connectivity to the rest of the UK and the world. Ta-ta to boosting tourism and exports, and all those other benefits the party had argued would follow the tax cut.As of yesterday morning, the SNPrsquos website continued to state that ldquoUK Air Passenger Dutyis one of the most expensive taxes of its kind in the world and hampers Scotlandrsquos ability to secure new direct international routes and maintain existing ones. Indeed, the level of taxation on the tourism sector, taking account of both VAT and APD, is amongst the highest in the world. This relatively high burden of taxation restricts the potential of the sector to grow to attract many more visitors to Scotland.Greens: The positive way to fight climate changeBut forget all that. As Derek Mackay, the Finance Secretary, told the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday, cutting the tax ldquois no longer compatible with more ambitious climate targets. So yoursquoll have had your cheaper holidays and the chance to turbo charge the economy.Business is angry about the sudden U-turn on a policy that has been in place for eight years. Liz Cameron, director of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said the move would do nothing to reduce emissions. Others have asked why,the government is so keen to tackle climate change, it is spending pound million to keep Prestwick airport open. Glasgow Prestwick Airport.It is no use complaining, however. As Roseanna Cunningham, the Environment Secretary, pointed out,everyone is in agreement that the planet is facing a climate emergency then politicians must act in the national and international interest, ldquoand not just what suits party political purposes.How magnanimous. How fortunate, moreover, that this reinvigorated dedication to the cause comes in a parliament where support of the Greens is vital in passing the administrationrsquos budget and other measures.But again, who are we to quibble  Itrsquos an emergency. We are at war with the clock in trying to make good the damage caused by centuries of pillaging the Earthrsquos resources. Someone has to pay, so it is us, in the here and now. Shut up and eat your green policies.No one would deny that there is a need to change our ways, but you do wonderwe have thought through the costs and impact and whether they are being imposed fairly. We have moved from inaction to wholesale acceptance of green policies with barely a pause to querythe right choices are being made. If it is green, it must be good is the guide.Fighting climate change at homeYet one personrsquos hero stopping the traffic is another personrsquos pain in the neckyou need to get to work. A workplace parking levy might seem like a good way to persuade people out of their cars, but why should the chief executive pay the same as the cleaner  Is it fair to push more people on to public transport when the system is badly stretched and barely managing as it is  And who should be exempt from parking charges: NHS staff, teachers, civil servants All questions worth asking, yet to do so risks the wrath of the more militant wing of the green lobby, a group that,it is not careful, will soon be alienating more people than it persuades. Look at what is already happening on the roads. Like a lot of other people, I would like to cycle rather than drive. Yet when you see the antagonism between cyclists and drivers it does not seem worth the risk.From this week, in response to the number of cyclists injured, undercover police are to take to bikes to enforce the rules on overtaking. Those who drive too close and are caught face three penalty points on their licence. A reasonable enough response to such thoughtless actions.But thoughtlessness is not the sole preserve of drivers. It is not unusual to see cyclists travelling in packs that are dficult to pass, causing frustration among motorists. On my way into work there is a stretch of road that includes dedicated cycle lanes. It cost a small fortune to create them, and the disruption caused lasted for months, yet a lot of cyclists will not use them. Then there are the bikes on pavements, the cyclists who jump traffic lights and the ones, albeit a minority, who seem to see it as their duty to be aggressive.Clock is ticking nowSelfish and dangerous behaviour on the part of cyclists and drivers should not happen, and it wouldnrsquotthe system of give and take, of compromise, was working as it should. But one side feels penalised by the other. The more people feel green policies are an imposition on particular groups, rather than something that benefits us all, the more ision will occur.In such sensitive times it does not help for policymakers to so blatantly play politics with environmental matters, as has happened with the air tax cut U-turn. Looking after the planet is a permanent job, not something to dabble in when the mood strikes.

title: scottish-deposit-return-scheme-cans-and-bottles-to-carry-20p-deposit-to-save-waste
story: In an announcement at Holyrood on Wednesday, Scottish Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said the scheme would place avalue on items of p and would be up and running by the end of the current Parliament in .It means Scotland will become the first part of the UK to introduce such a scheme, which aims to capture % of drinks containers for recycling within three years.:Effort behind innovative depositscheme cannot go to wasteIn her statement to MSPs, Ms Cunningham said the scheme will apply to PET plastic bottles ndash for example fizzy drinks and water bottles ndash glass bottles and steel aluminium drinks cans.She also detailed her decision not to include high density polyethyleneplastic ndash primarily used for packaging fresh milk ndash in the scheme, due to concerns over potential contamination of other materials and odour.Ms Cunningham said HDPE could be added at a later stagesuch concerns are addressed.A ldquo to retail service will be implemented as part of the scheme, with all businesses which sell drinks required to accept s.Smaller retailers, Ms Cunningham said, would be given flexibility in how they enable s through dferent sizes of reverse vending machines or manual over-the-counter take-back arrangements.We were the first part of the UK to commit to a #DepositReturn scheme as part of our wider efforts to increase recycling  prevent discarded drinks containers from ending up in our streets  seas,  are now the first to outline its design https:t.co IjvdAtxh pic nRhzEnZKmdash Scot Gov GreenerMay , At premises such as pubs and restaurants where drinks are sold for consumption on site, Ms Cunningham confirmed those premises would pay the deposit but would have the choice whether to pass it on to the consumer.:Morrisons trials plastic depositscheme in supermarketsShe told MSPs: ldquoI acknowledge that our plans are ambitious. Whilst I make no apology for this, I also do not underestimate the scale of the task. I look forward to working with partners to plan next steps.ldquoI remain very open to working with the other UK administrations which are currently consulting on DRS . However this must be on the basis that their ambition matches our own.ldquoOur climate change commitments mean it is simply not an option for us to wait in the hope that others will follow the example we are now setting.ldquoWith that said, Irsquom optimistic that the bold approach we are taking here in Scotland will provide a blueprint for future action across the UK.Jill Farrell, chief operating officer at Zero Waste Scotland, said: ldquoThis will be a game-changer for recycling and the circular economy in Scotland.ldquoBy giving people an extra incentive to do something good for our environment, and having a consistent approach across Scotland, we are confident it will be easier for all of us to do the right thing.ldquoThis will improve the volume and quality of recycling and help tackle litter in the process.Scottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoA depositscheme can be a valuable tool in increasing recycling rates but is commonly used in advance of kerbside recycling infrastructure roll-out.ldquoNevertheless, I recognise that the SNP Government has been working on this scheme for over a decade and so I expect the smoothest possible roll-out.Scottish Liberal Democrat energy spokesman Liam McArthur said introducing the scheme is the right thing to do in order to end the countryrsquos throwaway culture.He said: ldquoAs we iron out the details it is essential that there are no unintended consequences.ldquoIsland and rural areas must be properly accounted for, and we need to be certain that the inclusion of glass wonrsquot cause manufacturers to turn to more harmful materials.ldquoThe next step must be moving urgently to tackle the mountain of coffee cup waste through a latte levy, preventing millions of cups going straight to landfill.

title: scots-rail-firm-sues-uk-government-over-ban
story: The Perth-based transport giant is claiming the DfT breached its statutory duties over its move to ban Stagecoach from bidding on the East Midlands rail franchise.It says it is also considering legal action against the department over ongoing competitions for the West Coast Partnership and a new South Eastern franchises, both also under DfT restrictions.The firmrsquos rail expansion plans looked to have been left in shreds after the firm was disqualied from bidding for the three franchises, one of which was awarded to the firm that operates ScotRail, Abellio.:Stagecoach banned from competing for rail franchisesChris Grayling, the transport secretary, said then the Government had agreed a plan with Abellio East Midlands that it expects will result in the firm exceeding the expectations set under a highly demanding and challenging specication for the franchise, which Stagecoach has run for  years.The DfT also said at that point the firm had breached the rules of the competition citing concerns about pensions costs, and a spokesman said that the department has ldquototal confidence in our franchise competition process and will robustly defend decisions that were taken fairly.Concerns centre on who should pay the bill for meeting pensions liabilities for rail workers, which the Government has shouldered historically.Stagecoach Group, founded by bus and trains magnate Sir Brian in , said a claim has been issued at the High Court in London which alleges that the DfT ldquobreached its statutory duties hellip in connection with the procurement of the new East Midlands rail franchise.:Stagecoach suffers rail reverse as ScotRail operator advancesThe firm said: ldquoWe have informed the DfT that we are also preparing a claim for judicial review of its decisions to disqualy us from bidding for the East Midlands rail franchise and to award the franchise to Abellio.ldquoAdditionally, we are considering legal action against the DfT in respect of the ongoing competitions for the West Coast Partnership franchise and a new South Eastern franchise.It said one claim has been issued and the further legal actions under preparation ldquoy in certain respects but common to all is our refusal to accept the potential pension risks that the DfT requires operators to bear in relation to the three new franchises.Stagecoach said: ldquoThe full extent of these risks is unknown but we estimate them to be well in excess of pound billion.:Rail firm reveals franchise pension bill would have topped poundbnMartin Grfiths, Stagecoach Group chief executive, said: ldquoWe remain deeply concerned at the DfTrsquos procurement of the three most recent rail franchise competitions and the rationale behind its decisions.ldquoDespite our continued requests for full transparency around these matters, many fundamental questions remain unanswered. As a result, regrettably we have had no option but to commence legal action against the DfT to ensure the serious issues involved and the DfTrsquos opaque decision-making are subject to proper public scrutiny.ldquoIn view of the legal action we have taken today we believe it would be untenable for the DfT to proceed to sign any contract for the East Midlands franchise without a full and proper review of the procurement of that franchise to help restore public confidence in the process.:Turner Prize drops Stagecoach sponsor over gay laws rowA DfT spokesman said: ldquoStagecoach is an experienced bidder who knowingly submitted non-compliant bids on all competitions. In doing so, they disqualied themselves.ldquoWe do not comment on legal proceedings. However, we have total confidence in our franchise competition process and will robustly defend decisions that were taken fairly following a thorough and impartial evaluation process.Stagecoach shares closed marginally up ndash .p ndash at p.

title: which-scotrail-among-the-uks-worst-operators-for-delay-repay-compensation
story: Consumer group Which  said its study of online claim forms shows customers seeking payouts for disruption face a "fragmented and confusing" system.The operators with the most complicated compensation processes were found to be Great Anglia, London Northwestern, ScotRail, Transport for Wales and West Midlands Trains.Read more:More complaints over ScotRail disruption four months after winter timetable chaosEach demands  separate details before a claim can be submitted.Which  found that customers are often asked for "seemingly irrelevant details" which creates "unnecessary barriers" to receiving the money they are owed.Whichs managing director of public markets, Alex Hayman, said: "Its clear this fragmented and confusing compensation system leads to people losing out on a lot of money when they have already suffered enough from unacceptable levels of delays and cancellations."The technology exists to deliver compensation automatically, but the industry continues to drag its heels, while benefiting from a system that deters passengers from claiming the money they are owed."Read more: Revealed - the stations most often skipped by ScotrailThe scheme by ScotRail - owned by Abellio - has been described as "cynical" and triggered renewed calls for services to be owned by the public.TSSA union leader Manuel Cortes said: "On top of suffering the worst punctuality and reliability since Scotlands railways were privatised, now ScotRail passengers have to navigate a Byzantine claims process and provide  pieces of information in order to claim compensation for the delays."This is pure cynical greed. Abellio know that the harder it is for passengers to claim a refund the more likely they are to give up on the process."Read more: Scotrail still year away from hitting punctuality targetsScottish Conservative transport spokesman Jamie Greene said: "Obviously some level of detail is required to safeguard against fraud but its hard to see how  pieces of information could be necessary."If ScotRail made it more straightforward it would much improve goodwill between them and passengers, something which is sadly severely lacking at present."Scottish Labour transport spokesman Colin Smyth said: "This is cynical stuff from ScotRail, given the thousands of passengers who will suffer from delayed, cancelled and overcrowded trains."Passengers shouldnt have to jump through hoops to get the compensation they are due for a shambolic service."Labour would bring our railways back into public hands so they work for passengers, not profits."The firms delay repay guarantee allows customers to be compensated when their journey is delayed by  minutes or more.If anyone misses a connection because of that delay, they can claim for that expense too.A ScotRail spokesman said: "We know how much of an inconvenience it is to customers when things dont go to plan, and it is only right that they are compensated when that happens."The delay repay system is easy to use and we regularly remind our customers to claim for compensationtheir journey is delayed by  minutes or more."

title: scottish-devolution-key-pieces-of-legislation
story: Mental HealthScotland Act Introduced in September , this was the first legislation passed following the opening of the Parliament earlier that year. It had aimed to close a loophole in the law that had led to the release of convicted killer Noel Ruddle, who had shot dead his neighbour with an assault rle. The bill added public safety to the grounds for not discharging certain patients detained under the Mental HealthAct . However, it was repealed in October .Ethical Standards in Public Le, etc.Act Section  was scrapped by MSPs from this broad legislation, which also set out a code of conduct for councillors. Section A of the Local Government Act had banned the promotion of homosexuality in schools, but removedas part of the legislation underpart  of the act, which focused on childrenrsquos teaching and welfare.Education Act Upfront tuition fees wereabolished in Scotland after MSPs voted to replace them with an endowment fee. The legislation meant students would only pay a pound, graduate fee, with repayment starting when earnings hit pound,. The endowment fee was removed by MSPs in February .Community Care and HealthAct In February , MSPs voted unanimously in favour of plans to provide free personal care for the elderly. The legislation meant all personal care charges for people cared for in their own home were abolished, while everyone needing nursing care would receive it free of charge.Homelessness, etc.Act The Smoking, Health and Social CareAct A ban on smoking in bars, restaurants and all public places was approved by MSPs in June , with the change coming into effect in March . Employers could be finedthey failed to enforce the ban and smokers could also face a finethey were found to be lighting up. The then Health Minister, Scottish Labour MSP Andy Kerr, described it as being the most important piece of public health legislation in a generation.Alcohol Act Scottish Independence Referendum Act The legislation that paved the way for a referendum onindependence was passed in November  and set out a series of rules for the vote, such as the question and campaign spending limits. Separate legislation allowing - and -year-olds to vote had already been passed. The referendum was held in September , with a turnout of almost . per cent ndash a record for any election held inthe UK since the introductionof universal suffrage in.Marriage and Civil PartnershipAct MSPs backed a bill that would allow same-sex marriages in Scotland in November , which passed in February . The Scottish Government said at the time the move was the right thing to do, despiteScotlandrsquos two main churches opposing it. The law came into effect on December  that year, with some of the first marriages taking place on Hogmanay after the usual -day notice period for marriages.Domestic Abuse Act The Scottish Parliament voted by  to one to bring changes to laws on domestic abuse inScotland. Under the legislation, a specic offence of ldquoabusive behaviour in relation to apartner or ex-partner was created, widening the scope for prosecution, having previously primarily focused on domestic abuse of a physical nature. Scottish Conservative MSP Margaret Mitchell, who had recorded the only vote against the legislation, later explained that she had pressed the wrong button during the vote and that she was, in fact, in favour of the changes.

title: how-the-yes-campaign-delivered-a-new-scottish-parliament
story: Scotland Forward chairman Nigel Smith declared: ldquoUnderlying this campaignare the lessons of history of years ago which put a deep mark in the psyche of the nation as to how not to do things when you conduct a referendum campaign."We need toprovide a single, unyingforce in Scotland during this campaign.rsquorsquoHe was, of course, referring to the  devolution referendum, which was won by Yes but on a low turnout.Scotland Forward was determined that there would be no such heartbreak this time.Smith spoke of the need foran inclusive campaign that captured the mood of the nation.A strong anti-devolution message was a feature ofthe Scottish Conservative conference, in late June.Former scottish secretary Michael Forsyth compared those who kept up the fight against devolution to the ancient Spartans, and insisted it was still possible to win the war.Devolution was not cost free, he added, and there would be a ldquohigh price to pay for the extra politicians on Calton Hill.Looking ahead to the referendum on September , Lord James Douglas Hamilton told the conference: lsquo"The next test of our mettle will be in two monthsrsquo time. We should now be firing a warning shot across the bows of the [Tony Blair] Government saying its plans are regressive, bureaucratic, and a folly in upsetting the level playing field and threatening inward investment.rsquorsquoBut as Professor TomDevine records in his book, Independence Or Union, the pro-home rule camp was ldquounited as never before.The SNP, Labour and the Liberal Democrats ndash under, respectively, Alex Salmond, Donald Dewar and Jim Wallace ndash campaigned vigorously.The opposing camp, Devine observes, was weak by comparison. ldquoScottish business, which had vocerously condemned devolution in , was mainly silent ... lsquoThink Twicersquo, theanti-devolution campaign, had few of the financial resourcesor personalities of the organizations that opposed devolution in .The fate of the lsquoNorsquo campaigners was sealed, Mr Devine adds, when Margaret Thatcher gave them her public support.On Radio rsquos The Reunion programme, Jim Wallace, now Lord Wallace, said: ldquoI remember it being a very positive campaign amongst those of us who supported the Parliament. Itrsquos fair to say it was a fairly lacklustre campaign to start with, and then there was the tragic death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and it was agreed among all the parties that we would suspend the campaign until after the funeral, and in these final three or four days it was very intense.The extent of public enthusiasm for a Scottish parliament was reflected in the scale of the vote on September : On a turnout of .%, .% of the electorate backed a parliament, with .% in favour of it having tax-raising powers.When the Queen openedthe new Parliament on July , , First Minister Donald Dewar gave, to quote Mr Devinersquos words, ldquomany consider to be the greatest speech of his le, with its eloquent evocations of the Scottish past and hopes for the future of the nation.ldquoThis is indeed a moment anchored in our history, said Mr Dewar. A few lines later,he added: ldquoToday, we look forward to the time when this moment will be seen as a turning point: the day when democracy was renewed in Scotland, when we revitalised our place in this our United Kingdom. This is about more than our politics and our laws. This is about who we are, how we carry ourselves.And as the SNP MSP Winnie Ewing took the oath she declared: ldquoThe Scottish Parliament, adjourned on the th day of March in the year , is hereby reconvened.

title: herald-diary-fitba-crazy-and-a-brief-encounter-with-alcohol
story: FANTASTIC win by Liverpool the other night against Barcelona. It somehow reminds us of the Provost of Fe no less, Jim Leishman, the former footballer and manager who once spoke at a charity dinner in Glasgow and explained: "As a young player I could have signed for Liverpool, Manchester United, or Cha." Jim added after a pause: "But none of them wanted me, so I signed for Dunfermline."If Liverpool go on to win the European Championship, Jurgen Klopp will be regarded as one of their greatest managers, alongside Scotlands Bill Shankly of course. The book Scottish Sporting Legends told of Shankly berating forward Tony Hateley for his lack of talent. Defending himself, Tony declared: "You have to admit Im great in the air." But Shankly tartly replied: "Ill grant you that son, but so was Douglas Bader, and he had two better legs than youll ever have."Driven to itMORE on student days, as John Crawford in Lytham recalls: "Years ago I was on a packed train travelling to Glengarnock. The only vacant seat was beside a drunk who took several swigs from a half-bottle, before offering me a swig that I politely declined. On learning I was at Strathclyde he said, I bet youre one of these students that only drinks beer  I agreed. He then pulled out a can of Tennents, tore off the ring-pull, took a deep swig and said, This ones yours. It was only with some dficulty that I managed to convince him that my car was parked at the station ndash it wasnt ndash and I never took drink when I was driving."TrumpedTHE New York Times reported that President Donald Trump had personal business losses of more than  billion over a -year period from . We asked one of his supporters in Newton Mearns to comment and he replied: "You see, I told you he was a billionaire."Bottled itIT sounds complicated, but the Scottish Government announced it is going ahead with plans to introduce a deposit scheme of p on plastic and glass drinking bottles as well as cans. No doubt grandfathers will be reminiscing with their grandchildren about making a fortune collecting bottles at football grounds after the games ndash although you had to be careful with any full of a warm liquid. One reader even told us about his local shop only taking back bottles they had sold, and to prove it, would have them stamped with their own sign. Enterprising kids would cut a similar stamp out of a potato, dip it in ink and recreate the sign on any bottle. We think the film The Great Escape had a lot to answer for.Speedy responseHAVE been dodging a certain colleague for a while but he came over yesterday and declared: "Im doing a story on rejected questions from Scottish examination papers. One of them began, A car is going at constant speed of mph on the M from Glasgow to Edinburgh. I mean, on what imaginary universe is it in "Under pressureWE mentioned the enjoyment men get from using a pressure hose in the garden. A reader phones to tell us: "Yes, they are good fun ndash until you are almost finished washing the patio and the we comes home and bursts your bubble by asking you to show her the bit you think is done."Hard to faceAFTER The Herald news story yesterday that said people are having less sex these days, a reader phones to explain: "I blame all these pictures of Nigel Farage on the television news."

title: letters-history-shows-blairs-world-view-to-be-wrong
story: World history says otherwise. Since ,  countries have become independent of Britain. There are twice as many UN members as there were when it was founded. In  there were  independent countries in Europe. Today: .No country which achieved independence has asked to be taken back.Mr Blair is disingenuous when he equates a club of nations such as the EU, EFTA or the Nordic Council where each member has a vote and gets a turn to be convener with a hierarchical arrangement like the UK where only one country calls the shots and the rest ndash who may have a very dferent political philosophy ndash are not consulted.A grown-up child earns and spends and chooses a lestyle which may be dferent from that of the parents. A wise parent does not confuse this loss of control over the child with loss of affection.Mary McCabe,Glasgow G.IM afraid I cant feel any sympathy for Tony Blair when he complains that "people like Alex Salmond were very harsh critics in a very personal way" . However, I do agree with his analysis of why the once-dominant Labour Party has become a political backwater in Scottish politics. As Mr Blair points out, " you take a series of wrong decisions you end up with a bad result". No doubt the people of Iraq are also very harsh critics of Mr Blair, in a very personal way.Ruth Marr,Stirling.THE Scottish Government climb-down on aviation tax Sturgeon put climate before poundm tax cut", The Herald, May  is just the latest in an embarrassing series of events which, quite frankly, is making Scotland look ridiculous. It is bad enough that after demanding further powers in relation to welfare payments, more than three years down the line the only money spent has been on setting up a system which is still not ready to operate. Millions of pounds wasted, and Scotland presented as ineffectual.Now we have Derek Mackay, Cabinet Secretary for Finance, Economy and Fair Work, claiming that his U-turn on aviation tax is because a UK Government committee failed to tell him that climate change is a serious problem. Perhaps he should have a word with John Swinney, Cabinet Secretary for Education and Skills, who could point out the relevant sections in Curriculum for Excellence which deal with climate change and sustainability. We expect school children to have an understanding of this issue. The Cabinet Secretarys statement smacks of "It wisnae me".The last straw in the recent evidence of SNP incompetence is First Minster Sturgeons infamous tweet poking fun at Ruth Davidson using a leaked recording of Ms Davidsons rehearsal for her conference speech. The First Minster tries to present herself as a player on the international stage. Can anyone imagine Angela Merkel or Emmanuel Macron stooping to this level of public debate  Yet again, Scotland is diminished by SNP behaviour.Over the last  years the SNP has been handed a golden opportunity to demonstrate its competence in improving le in Scotland. Instead, it has damaged our education system, failed to meet health targets, undermined the police and presided over a rail system which consistently fails passengers. Its failure to act in the manner we are entitled to expect from government ministers is just the icing on their cake.Carole FordGlasgow G.DESPITE Ian Lakinrsquos protestations , trade between the US and Canada works just fine, as anyone who has seen Die Hard With a Vengeancecan testy, as the denouement takes place at a truck stop on the Canada  US border.He is correct that today the value of a Canadian dollar is US ., but because the two currencies float freely, the rate of exchange between Canada and the US ies. The -year average of the Canadian dollar against the US dollar is ., and between  and  the Canadian dollar traded near or above par against the US dollar. But while Mr Lakin does his best to belittle Canada, according to the World Economic Forumrsquos global comparison, it had the second-best quality of le, just behind Finland.Lastly, he resurrects the corpse of ldquoyou will have to join the euro, arguing on the basis of an unknown source, that an independent Scotland would not be ldquofully compatible otherwise. Then again, we could say the same of the nine member states, including Sweden and Poland, who currently donrsquot use the euro. The EU view is clear from a document entitled ldquoThe  Convergence Report: Review of Member States progress towards euro adoption, and specically under a question ldquoAre Member States obliged to join the euro , where we are told ldquoIn principle, all Member States that do not have an opt-out clausehave committed to adopt the euro once they fulfil the necessary conditions. However, it is up to inidual countries to calibrate their path towards the euro and no timetable is prescribed.There is general agreement that in negotiating EU membership Scotland would have to commit to joining the euro, but it would be more candid for those opposing independence to accept that we would not ndash could not ndash join on independence and that thereafter, to quote the EU itself, ldquono timetable is prescribed, evenour electorate approved doing so.Alasdair Galloway,Dumbarton.

title: devolved-scottish-benefit-payment-inundated-with-applications-from-rest-of-uk
story: Families on low incomes have been able to apply for part of the Best Start Grant, which helps cover the costs of having a baby, since December.But officials in charge of the new devolved benefit were taken aback when  per cent of the applicants ndash more than , ndash came from outside Scotland.Social Security Secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville said it signalled that there needed to be ldquoclearer eligibility around residency criteria on the application form.She said: ldquoThere are a very signicant number of applications that we were getting in for Best Start Grant that were not from people in Scotland, and we therefore had to adapt that.It came as Holyroodrsquos Social Security Committee took evidence on the delivery of a tranche of benefits devolved to Scotland in .Last week, Scotlandrsquos spending watchdog found there is a ldquosignicant risk the Scottish Government will fail to deliver billions of pounds-worth of the welfare payments on time.Auditor General Caroline Gardner said the new benefits agency had only managed to deliver its first, relatively easy payments by working ldquoflat out and relying on costly agency staff.But it now faces a struggle to introduce a second wave of more complex benefits which account for  per cent of the pound.bn due to be paid to .m claimants each year by .Speaking to MSPs, Ms Somerville said officials had now ensured that applicants are asked ldquoDo you live in Scotland  right at the start of the process.She said: ldquoClearly we have to test eligibility, but itrsquos perhaps not something that we thought wersquod have to really point out as stringently as we did. story: Ground and site investigation work has been programmed for a number of locations between York Place and Newhaven, starting in Lindsay Road in the week commencing May .Separately - but planned in conjunction with these works - pound million over five years -will include resurfacing the carriageway, pedestrian access and public realm improvements and traffic signal upgrades well as signalising the junction at Easter Road Lochend Road and Duke Street.Information about the ground andsite investigation and road resurfacing projects will be communicated to directly-affected residents and businesses in advance of work starting.Alejandro Mendoza, SFN project director, said:ldquoThese ground investigation works are vital to our early involvement."The information we obtain on the ground conditions will allow our design team to develop a robust final design."It will also help us inform key elements such as the construction plan and any effects that may have on traffic management arrangements.Lesley Macinnes, transport convener, said:ldquoTherersquos going to be a fair bit of work going on in and around the Leith Walk area over the next few months and wersquore keen to make sure people have as much information as possible about whatrsquos happening and why."Both projects are aimed at helping the Trams to Newhaven construction phase go as smoothly as possible.: Scots rail firm sues UK Government over banThe final business case for the extension revealed the cost could reach pound million.The potential hike is poundm more than the previously cited poundm, andincludes a contingency fund.

title: bbc-lacked-in-depth-knowledge-during-scottish-independence-referendum
story: BBC staffer, Alistair Burnett, who was involved in the referendum coverage, made the claims in a special report by the Scottish Centre on European Relations The report, titledThe Future ofEurope: Disruption, Continuity And Change,contained comments by former BBC broadcaster Alistair Burnett, who has since left the BBC.:FMQs: Nicola Sturgeon and Ruth Davidson face off for first time in seven monthsSpeaking to our sister paperThe National he added that he believed the BBC had made a mistake in sending correspondents based in London to cover the referendum campaign in Scotland.In the SCER report, Burnett wrote: ldquoIn terms of public service broadcasting, the BBC faces its most critical audiences in Scotland, where levels of dissatisfaction with the public broadcaster are higher than where in the UK.ldquoThis dissatisfaction with the BBC increased during the independence campaign, as the broadcaster was perceived by independence supporters to be failing in its duty to be impartial.ldquoI was still working at a senior level in BBC News in London at the time and, although I never saw deliberate bias, a lack of in-depth knowledge about Scotland and a lack of sympathy for Scottish independence among many BBC staff were clear and mistakes in coverage were made.:Scottish Tories branded an embarrassment over EU election letterBurnett told The National: ldquoI think it was a mistake to send the London Westminster-based correspondents up to Scotland rather than use the people there who in my view did know what they were talking about, such as Brian Taylor. ldquoSNP depute leader Brown said: ldquoThese comments by Alistair Burnett follow on from what Allan Little said about the BBCrsquos reporting of the  referendum and are true of the BBCrsquos ongoing problem with covering Scotland properly.ldquoTwenty years on from the opening of the Scottish Parliament,  years on from the King Report and yet still the BBC network regularly falls short when it comes to reporting not just from Scotland but across the nations and regions.ldquoThe corporationrsquos London-centric view persists. It is vital that the BBC addresses these persistent failings.ldquoThe corporation bosses in London need to be transparent as to how it plans to improveit is to stand a chance of winning back the trust that they themselves admit they have lost.A BBC spokesperson said: ldquoOur audiences in Scotland told us that they wanted more relevant content and thatrsquos why we launched both a new channel, that includes a new daily news programme, and increased the number of network programmes made in Scotland for viewers across the UK.ldquoThat annual poundm investment is the biggest in a generation and we believe it will better serve audiences as well as boost the creative sector in Scotland.

title: david-beckham-receives-six-month-driving-ban
story: The football star, , previously pleaded guilty to using the device while driving in Great Portland Street, after being spotted by a member of the public on November .His case was initially considered at Bromley Magistrates Court last month, through an administrative process known as a single justice procedure, which is not open to the press or public.Beckham, who appeared in the same court wearing a dark grey suit and tie, was told by District Judge Catherine Moore that he would be disqualied as she gave him six additional points to the six he already had for previous speeding matters.The star stood in court to say his full name, date of birth and his west London address.Prosecutor Matthew Spratt said Beckham was photographed by a member of public as he drove in "slowly moving" traffic while holding a phone.He said: "Instead of looking straight forward, paying attention to the road, he appeared to be looking at his lap."He added: "Hesays that the defendant was operating a handheld device at knee level. At that moment a photograph was taken."The defendant was holding the mobile phone in the upright position."Gerrard Tyrrell, mitigating, said his client was travelling slowly and has "no recollection of the day in question or this particular incident".He added: "There is no excuse for what took place but his view is as he cannot remember... hes going to plead guilty and thats what hes done."Beckham was also fined pound, ordered to pay pound to prosecution costs and a pound surcharge fee within seven days.

title: revealed-fruitmarket-gallerys-plans-for-extension-in-centre-of-edinburgh
story: The Fruitmarket Gallery, in Edinburghs Market Street, next to Waverley Station, has submitted a planning application to Edinburgh City Council for the refurbishment of its existing gallery building at  Market Street.It plans to convert the adjacent warehouse building at  to  Market Street, which for many years was the Electric Circus venue, into a new facility, a two storey-height space - formerly a fruit and vegetable warehouse - which will be used as a visual art, performance and music space.City councillors will consider the plan in July.Reiach and Hall Architects have revealed the designs for the project, which join the two properties with a ramped corridor.The existing main gallery spaces will remain unchanged, although access areas such as the stairs and the lt will be revamped, and new education spaces will be created in the extension.The project details are a new take on the gallerys long-held desire to expand, a simplied version of the gallerys initial poundm plan.Of the pound.m project cost, pound.m has already been raised.The Fruitmarket Gallery will close for refurbishment in July this year, and open again in .During this time the Fruitmarket said it will be working with artists "out in the community and offsite."Fiona Bradley, the director of The Fruitmarket Gallery, said: "This project has opportunities for artists and audiences at its heart.Neil Gillespie, director, Reiach and Hall Architects, said: "The new warehouse spaces are designed enter into a critical and dynamic dialogue with the original galleries. As an ensemble, they offer artists, curators and audiences remarkable, contrasting and complementary spaces."The Fruitmarket attracted nearly , visitors in .Reiach and Hall Architects were formed in  and are one of only three practices in the UK to have been shortlisted for the prestigious RIBA Stirling Prize three years in a row .

title: nicola-sturgeon-launches-snp-election-campaign
story: The First Ministers also urged voters to ldquoend a message to Theresa May that Scotland had had had enough of being ignored.ldquoVote SNP to stop Brexit, she told party members at Our Dynamic Earth in Edinburg.The SNP leader said the May  poll was ldquoby far the most important European election in Scotlandrsquos history.She said: ldquoAt stake in this election is not just which parties and which candidates will be elected to the European Parliament.ldquoAt stake also is whether Scotland can remain inside the European Union at all.ldquoBy voting SNP, people in Scotland can send a clear and unequivocal message to Theresa May. That message is this: Scotland has had enough of being ignored.Tory MSP Jackson Carlaw said: ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos grievance-laden speech is yet further evidence of her real priority ndash not to come up with a sensible plan to deliver Brexit, but to use Brexit to push her only priority, another referendum on independence.ldquoThese elections on May rd are our chance to say no to Nicola Sturgeon and no to any more referendums ndash whether on independence or the European Union.ldquoThe choice is clear: Nicola Sturgeon has never met a referendum result she opposes.ldquoOur position is to respect the results of the referendum and get on with delivering a deal that backs our fishermen and our businesses, so we can all move on.Earlier, Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie launched his European campaign with the aim of regaining the MEP his party lost in  because of its coalition with the Tories.Arguing for a Peoplersquos Vote, he said: ldquoPeople are fed up with Brexit. It has caused ision in our country and damaged our economy. Voters now have the chance to make that stop by voting for the Liberal Democrats on rd May."A vote for the Liberal Democrats is a positive vote to solve these problems, prove the UK is an outward looking country and remain in the EU.At the last EU elections, the SNP and Labour each won two of the six seats in Scotland, and the Tories and Ukip won one each.The launches took place as around , postal ballot packs arrived with Scottish voters, around one in five of the electorate.

title: angus to brave charity catwalk
story: An Inverurie man is set to take part in a charity fashion show in Aberdeen tomorrow .Angus Mackie, , will head to the Beach Ballroom to participate in Brave, a fundraising event organised by local charity Friends of ANCHOR.More than just a fashion show, Brave recognises the strength and tenacity of  men who have all faced a cancer diagnosis - both past and present. Angus is the oldest model in the Brave line-up, but age certainly isn’t an issue when it comes to his enthusiasm, and he has brought so much charisma and style to catwalk rehearsals.He said: “I’ve really enjoyed taking part in weekly rehearsals and meeting other men who have been, or are going through, through similar experiences.“Talking to others can be a big help and the weekly meet-ups have been good fun.”For Angus, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in August last year, getting involved with Brave is all about raising awareness and encouraging others.He said: “Even though I have cancer and cannot do anything to stop it, hopefully I can help raise money and awareness to find a cure.“For anyone who is going through a similar experience, I would say do all you can to always remain positive, live le to the full, andpossible, try to join a cancer or support group – I did and found it very therapeutic talking with others living with cancer.”This year, every penny raised from Brave will be ring-fenced for Friends of ANCHOR’s fundraising campaign, the ANCHORED Together appeal, which aims to raise £m for the new, multi-million-pound ANCHOR Centre.The first of its kind in Scotland, it is estimated the Centre will be used by , patients a year.The NHS Grampian ANCHOR Centre is set to open at Foresterhill in late .In the run-up to the shows, all of the models have been professionally styled and trained by the production and model agency Premiere Productions UK.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: charity and brewdog to create sensory haven for dogs
story: The Scottish SPCA, in partnership with BrewDog, is to create a sensory garden for dogs at their animal rescue and rehoming centre in Drumoak.Scotland’s animal welfare charity cares for thousands of animals who have been abused, injured or abandoned each year.Many arrive scared and very unsure of their surroundings and some arrive as puppies who have only experienced a kennelled environment.Centre manager Graeme Innes said: “We are absolutely delighted to be creating a sensory garden with BrewDog and are honoured they have chosen to do this with us.“Many of the dogs in our care come from unfortunate circumstances and adapting to kennel le can be dficult for them.“The sensory garden will be full of dferent dog friendly elements and scents which help encourage dogs to use their senses and provides physical and mental stimulation within the surroundings.“The garden will include dferent surfaces and textures which will be fun for the dogs, as well as many other objects to keep them entertained.“The garden will also be designed to include a safe, quiet area for them to relax in.“This will be an equal collaboration, using the expertise of our team and tapping into the creativity of BrewDog.They’ve already given us lots to think about, I think the dficulty will be narrowing all the great ideas down.“We’re so grateful to BrewDog for this incredible opportunity and we very much look forward to working with them. We created a sensory garden in Glasgow and it’s proved to greatly enhance the dogs’ behaviours whilst in our care and moving forward into their forever homes so we can’t wait to get started.”BrewDog co-founder James Watt said: “Here at BrewDog, our story has always been heavily influenced by our four-legged friends. From the original BrewDog, Bracken, overseeing the first operations back in , we want to ensure that no man, womanis ever left behind. So supporting this fantastic Scottish SPCA initiative was a no brainer - we want to give these dogs the best new start we possibly can.”The sensory garden will begin construction this month with hopes for completion in June .data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Ali and Jonny Aspden take part in the Link Up Challenge"  Customers challenged to Link Up viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie man to kiltwalk for third time
story: An Inverurie man is preparing to tackle the -mile Aberdeen Kiltwalk for a third time next month.Iain Hay has decided to challenge himself to complete the -mile Mighty Stride route to raise money for Aberdeen Cyrenians.The Aberdeen Kiltwalk will be held on Sunday, June .In previous years Iain has raised over £ by taking part in the annual event.As part of the Mighty Stride, Iain will start at Potarch Green, located in the Ballogie Estate, before heading through Blackhall Forrest and down to Banchory, before heading onwards to Crathes.From there Iain’s walk will continue through the scenic Aberdeenshire countryside to Peterculter before entering the city of Aberdeen, where the walk will finish at the Kiltwalk village located at Duthie Park.Iain commented: “I am, yet again, doing this personal challenge to raise funds for Aberdeen Cyrenians, a Scottish charity which provides services that meet all the ying needs of people affected by homelessness in Aberdeen and the surrounding area.“Their staff work very hard to support clients to meet their basic needs and realise their potential, and people can rely on staff for support, advice, practical assistance or even just a listening ear - no one is ever turned away.”Paul added: “Please support my personal Kiltwalk challenge to raise funds for this worthwhile charity, so they can continue to grow in providing a tremendous service to so often overlooked members of the local community.”To support Iain on his fundraising challenge donations can be given online at aberdeenkiltwalk.everydayhero uk iain.Iain has also provided sponsorship forms that can be found at many outlets around Inverurie, simply leave the amount you wish to give in the given sponsorship box.Iain will update his online fundraising page to show how his training for the event is progressing.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: inverurie theatre group seeks prop
story: Inverurie#s Spotlight Theatre Group is appealing for help to locate a VIP - a very important prop.Towards the end of the month the group will be performing their annual production in Inverurie Town Hall.This year the group will perform ‘A Bunch of Amateurs’ by Private Eye editor and ‘Have I Got News For You’ team captain Ian Hislop, and satirical cartoonist and comedy scriptwriter Nick Newman.The show tells the story of the Stratford Players who are trying to save their little theatre, a converted barn, from developers.They decide thatthey could get a Hollywood star to appear in their production of ‘King Lear’ then they might be able to save their local community theatre.The group contact Jefferson Steele, an American has-been movie action hero who arrives expecting to be acting with the likes of Sir Kenneth Branagh and Dame Judy Dench at The Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford Upon Avon.Much hilarity ensues as Jefferson’s monstrous ego, vanity and insecurity are tested by the enthusiastic amateur thespians - who are not averse to a spot of ego, vanity and insecurity themselves.Rehearsals in Inverurie are now moving into the final stages and all the backstage elements of set, props, costume, lighting and sound are beginning to come together.However one prop is proving rather dficult to source.Show director, Larry Young, is on the hunt for a mobility scooter.He said: “Hiring one for the week could prove quite expensive, and like any amateur theatre group we have to try and keep costs down.“We’re hoping that somebody out there might have a mobility scooter that they no longer require or that they could let us borrow for the week.”If anyone can help the group locate a mobility scooter for the show they are asked to please contact Larry on o .data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: new direction for aberdeenshire service
story: Aberdeenshire Voluntary Actionhas consolidated its operations to a new office located in Ellon town centre.AVA has also recruited a new Chief Executive Officer to lead the organisation, and is setting a new course for supporting volunteers and enabling communities and social enterprises across Aberdeenshire to deliver more sustainable services.AVA is Aberdeenshire’s Third Sector Interface , whose mission is to promote the growth of strong, resilient, communities by connecting, supporting, and representing volunteers, charities, community-led organisations, and social enterprises collectively referred to as the Third Sector.Funded by the Scottish Government, Aberdeenshire’s Health and Social Care Partnership, and its own Social Enterprise, the AVA team operates across the breadth of Aberdeenshire.AVA has a growing membership comprising of volunteers and organisations representing a erse cross-section of the Third Sector.AVA is currently redesigning its services to ensure that it fully represents those members and facilitates the amplication of their voice when and where critical future funding decisions are being made by Statutory Partners. To lead AVA in its development, the Board has appointed Daniel Shaw as its new Chief Executive Officer.Daniel is an experienced leader, having worked in the education, private and public sectors most recently with Aberdeenshire Council and the LEADER programme.David Hekelaar, Chair of AVA said: “AVA is emerging from a period of consolidation and Dan has the skills, experience and vision to take the organisation forward, for the benefit of all stakeholders, including Third Sector organisations, Aberdeenshire’s volunteers, our partners and our colleagues.”In a message to AVA members, Dan said it was a “great pleasure” to take up the new role.Aberdeenshire Voluntary Action can now be found at  Station Road in Ellon.For more details about AVA and how it may be able to benefit you or your organisation visit its website at www.avashire.org.uk or email enquiries@avashire.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.deesidepiper webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"BSG chairman Russ Crichton, right, with committee member Bruce Skinner at the skatepark ramp"  Banchory skatepark plans given boost viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "DEES | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "DEES | Article Teaser"

title: railway double tracking begins this weekend
story: From May  to August , the railway will undergo a series of closures to allow engineers to double the track between Dyce and Inverurie, carry-out bridge upgrades and deliver signalling enhancements.Engineers will double the track between Dyce and Inverurie, carry-out bridge upgrades and deliver signalling enhancementsThe -week programme is part of the Scottish Government-funded Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project.The following service alterations will be in place during the upgrade works: May ndashJune : Buses replace trains between Dyce and Inverurie.June ndashAugust : Buses replace trains between Dyce and Huntly.August ndashAugust : Bus replace trains between Aberdeen and Inverness.August ndashAugust : Buses replace trains between Aberdeen and Huntly.Over the  weeks, engineers will lay ten miles of rail over nearly , sleepers and replace or refurbish  bridges on the line.The work builds on the closure of the line between May and August  which saw the successful completion of the first phase of double-tracking between Aberdeen and Dyce.The Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project will increase capacity on the route improving services into the two cities.The benefits of the project for ScotRail customers include more services between Elgin and Inverness increasing during  until there is an hourly service all day providing , additional seats a half-hourly service all day between Inverurie and Aberdeen during , with extra services at peak times, providing , additional seats each day additional Elgin-Aberdeen early morning and late evening services InterCity trains operating between Aberdeen and Inverness, providing an extra , each day between the two cities and a new direct service between Inverurie and Montrose, reducing the need to change in Aberdeen.Billy McKay, Network Rail senior programme manager, said: ldquoDouble-tracking the line between Aberdeen and Inverurie will improve reliability on the route and allow a signicant title: sight loss support group to meet in inverurie
story: A new support group which aims to help increase the confidence and independence of people affected by sight loss is set to meet once a month in Inverurie.The group, which has been organised by leading sight loss charity the Macular Society, in partnership with local people, will hold its first full meeting on Thursday, May . title: uryside pupils help to create time capsule
story: Children at Uryside Primary School have helped to create a time capsule that will be sealed until .The time capsule has been made to mark the final few homes for sale at Taylor Wimpey’s Garioch View development of new homes in Inverurie.Uryside pupils were challenged to capture a snapshot of local le in .The time capsule has been buried within the communal central square of the Garioch View development and has been marked with a commemorative plaque.Working in their classes, the children have created an interesting picture of modern le in Uryside which is now sealed for the future and includes letters to their future self a poem, a selection of coins and photos of the bautul views from their school.They also included a copy of a newspaper, the current school menu and a school tie.The pupils fully embraced and enjoyed the project that was set for them by the team from Garioch View.Deputy head teacher David Shanks said: “This has been a fun and very dferent mission for the whole school to be involved in, and it’s an opportunity for the children to make a little bit of local history in their own town.“It has also been a great way for the children to think about the regular items they use and things they see in their everyday le and consider what children in the future will think of them in  years’ time.”Karen Armstrong, sales and marketing director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland added: “Our project with Uryside Primary School is a great way for us to capture some memories of what it’s like to be a child growing up in Inverurie now.“The children provided some great items that are now sealed until , marking the completion of our Garioch View development and developments in Aberdeenshire.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
